It's becoming clear that with all the brain and consciousness theories out there, the proof will be in the pudding. By this I mean, can any particular theory be used to create a human adult level conscious machine. My bet is on the late Gerald Edelman's Extended Theory of Neuronal Group Selection. The lead group in robotics based on this theory is the Neurorobotics Lab at UC at Irvine. Dr. Edelman distinguished between primary consciousness, which came first in evolution, and that humans share with other conscious animals, and higher order consciousness, which came to only humans with the acquisition of language. A machine with primary consciousness will probably have to come first.

What I find special about the TNGS is the Darwin series of automata created at the Neurosciences Institute by Dr. Edelman and his colleagues in the 1990's and 2000's. These machines perform in the real world, not in a restricted simulated world, and display convincing physical behavior indicative of higher psychological functions necessary for consciousness, such as perceptual categorization, memory, and learning. They are based on realistic models of the parts of the biological brain that the theory claims subserve these functions. The extended TNGS allows for the emergence of consciousness based only on further evolutionary development of the brain areas responsible for these functions, in a parsimonious way. No other research I've encountered is anywhere near as convincing.

I post because on almost every video and article about the brain and consciousness that I encounter, the attitude seems to be that we still know next to nothing about how the brain and consciousness work; that there's lots of data but no unifying theory. I believe the extended TNGS is that theory. My motivation is to keep that theory in front of the public. And obviously, I consider it the route to a truly conscious machine, primary and higher-order.

My advice to people who want to create a conscious machine is to seriously ground themselves in the extended TNGS and the Darwin automata first, and proceed from there, by applying to Jeff Krichmar's lab at UC Irvine, possibly. Dr. Edelman's roadmap to a conscious machine is at https://arxiv.org/abs/2105.10461

Of course we share many traits with our ancestors and those are not the virtuous kind. Hindu and Buddhist philosophies elucidated the 3 Elements of Monkey Mind thousands of years ago as monkeys are abundant throughout Asia and make for easy field observations. (It should be noted that the Big 3 Abrahamic religions were conceived in arid regions where monkeys were exotic curiosities and therefore were not investigated or scrutinized to guide understanding of ourselves). In fact, all the world's problems today could be attributed to Monkey Mind, the default mind-program of our species, and which operates in the background of every person on this Planet of the Apes. The 3 Elements of Monkey Mind are:
1) Limitless Greed - nothing is ever enough for us, especially if it is pleasurable to the senses or rewarding to the ego. EX: Got a pay raise? It's not enough, want more! Had a delicious meal? Not enough, want more! Got some sexy-time last night? Not enough, want more! Etcetera ad nauseam.
2) Tireless Fear - nothing in life is certain except uncertainty. Uncertainty is a Law of Physics. Yet uncertainty causes great unrest, angst, anxiety, and conflict in people. What we don't understand we fear and reject. Chronic Fear is crippling and causes many people to develop agoraphobia among other psychopathologies, on one side. On the other end of the stick, chronic fear creates control freaks who attempt to create certainty but often times fail.
3) IMPassive Dominance - monkeys seek highest position on the tree, especially when under threat. Likewise, people grasp and reach for higher status, greater achievements, higher commendations, more fame, etcetera ad nauseam. But as the saying goes, "the higher the monkey climbs, the more it reveals itself." This primitive program is seen throughout human history and in all relationships where dominance vs submission are constantly at play, at school, at work, and in interpersonal relationships.

However, transformation of Monkey Mind is possible and necessary if we are to continue to thrive and grow. In fact, one becomes a true Human Being by reforming Monkey Mind thus becoming a sharing and compassionate being. Understanding the 3 Elements of Monkey Mind is only the beginning and requires practice to have a breakthrough. The 3 Virtues that transform Monkey Mind, in respective order are:
1) Limitless Generosity - you will always have more than another in need and kindness does not cost anything. This practice alone can yield great merit and bring balance to our world.
2) Tireless Trust - trust is fundamental to human civilization and imperative to a happy secure life. Practicing trust opens up possibilities and reassures others security. Trust is essential to being a good human being.
3) Passive Abiding - The dominant are overturned by the submissive by bending down lower. The rigid crack and soft absorbs. On a deeper level, our essence is more like water than anything else. Water is the most powerful element in the universe (extinguishes fire, erodes rock, moves wind, and permeates all life) yet it is soft, smooth, and gentle. Water seeks its own level and transmutes states of matter (from solid, to liquid, to vapor, in endless repeating cycles). "Be like water"

Or, they simply process information faster which is due to travel at high speed through trees. You have to calculate the next branch to grab at very high speed or you fall and die. This leads to an effect where the chimp is seeing things like they're in slow motion. What appears to is as numbers for a fraction of a second, they experience as a longer amount of time. A similar effect happens to humans in car accidents or disasters. Things appear to be happening in slow motion to give more reaction time. We barely hang onto this old trait, while they use it daily in the forest.

Toddlers (2-3 year old) are better at fast memory visual tasks than adults (understandably not with numbers, but with drawings or symbols). I've seen it over and over when playing a card memory game with pairs. The only way an adult would win against a small child is if the adult makes a really conscious effort, with an unusual amount of focus, or develops a memorisation technique that requires practice. The child, who has a greater sense of observation (which doesn't require them any particular effort or focus), will win. It could fit with that cognitive tradeoff hypothesis, since at that age their language is still limited.

I'm always interested in matters of the brain & mind, especially as regarding every branch and limb of the human family tree.

I taught kids on the dyslexia spectrum for almost 2 decades. One of the programs was for students who could read, had age-appropriate or better vocabulary ...but could not recall the gestalt of the anything they tried to study for, enjoy, or learn.

Our idea was to have them to look at pictures and, in a series of different descriptive levels, report what they saw. Then we'd do blind confirmations, then they could check, and so on.

The next stage was for them to create a picture in their minds of each sentence we read ("What do those words make you picture?"), then rely on the images to answer questions.

(In this way we developed the strength in each side of the brain so that--very roughly speaking--the whole brain was flowing through information quickly without running into snags & stresses like studying for two weeks and passing a test but immediately forgetting everything, or failing.)

My point being--our students had pretty much all been born into a rich culture of language and while most may have had nerves around writing, talking was not usually an issue. The opposite of the chimps...
However once they began "seeing pictures," their concept imagery just went up and up.

I used to wonder, as I taught, about people on the savanna coming back to the group with reports of dangerous animals, game, storms...

My 2 cents worth if anyone cares. I've thought about this because I seem to be fairly good at some types of puzzles, but not others, and my thoughts are this: In this type of puzzle, your logic gets in the way because you are "saying" each number to yourself and trying to remember where it is on the grid, and you do this for each, one after another in sequence so that you can "assemble" the bits and store it to memory.
The chimp does not see the numbers, he sees shapes and he has learned the order they go in, so when it flashes for .5 seconds, he takes a single mental snapshot of a picture, so he sees the whole scene at once and which shape is where and holds that in short term memory. 1 fresh memory, not 10 little bits with dubious connections.
I bet if you took an artist and flashed blocks of color on the screen and told them to arrange in the spectrum, they would do very well - especially if they got snacks (it's how we're wired lol). Or even in the above, substitute the numbers for geometric shapes, but then you would have to mentally stop yourself labeling the shapes and just see them as part of the scene.
I suppose another way to put it would be to bypass the logical left hemisphere and focus and remember only with the creative right side - only problem - the left doesn't like getting left out.

Climb a tree in Africa.

Now, look for food in that tree, or any tree next to it.

As a primate, You are not a giraffe, and the leaves don't count.

All the good food is on the ground. Grows from the ground, or grows underground. And the best food lives on the ground and eats it. The best food with the most calories is fats/oils. Which come from nuts, and primarily consumption other animals.

I doubt our ancient predecessors got pushed out of the trees because they were weak. We became physically weak over time because they left the trees in search of better food.

This migration was enabled by our ancestors ability to think and reason first and foremost, in conjunction with our ability to communicate and work together.

Try getting a bunch of chimps, like 200 of them, to work together to to accomplish a task such as taking down a zebra or defending each other from a pride of lions.

Im aware that certain intelligent monkeys have learned to lure gazelles into false sense of security in order to feed their local pride of lions. They perform this task for generations and teach their offspring.

The lions never eat the monkeys, because they understand in some way that the monkeys help them survive. The monkeys are vastly more intelligent than the lions, therefore they are the ones who came up with the strategy through observation and reason.

This conspiracy of the monkeys to feed the lions by tricking the lesser-intelligent, purely instinctual prey animals goes on regularly in this day and age.

So, Im certain our ancestors worked out similar paw-shake agreements with predators, as many countless predators of higher intelligence seem to respect humans. E.g wolves, lions, hyenas, black bear, orcas, dolphins.

Whether our smart-ass ancestors developed tools before leaving the trees, who knows. But I suppose they probably threw rocks and used rocks to smash food, tubers, nuts, seashells, animal bones, etc.

Spears and thrown rocks might have been what enabled them to leave the forest entirely and congregate on the ground for sleep and resting. As there was probably many thousands if not millions of years overlap where they hunted on the ground and slept aloft before developing shelters and good pointy sticks.

Takeaway: Apes kicked out humans off the jungle as they were stronger and more agile. Humans evolved their communication skills (speaking) to share information to help them survive in the savannah to alert larger predators and coordinate hunting. The tradeoff consists of enabling language at the expense of short term memory.

A young Chimpanzee can count 10 apes of an enemy faction in their line of vision in the jungle and assess within 1 second if engaging in combat is worth the risk, flight, or flee. On the other hand, humans can sit in the jungle and spend half a minute counting inaccurately up to 5 angry apes in their line of sight before losing the count and decide to remain sitting still and pray for God to save them in their language.

I wonder if the memory difference has something to do with field of view or the focus of the eyes. When I was looking trying to follow along I noticed I only could see 1 or two numbers before they disappeared. Maybe chimps are able to see all the numbers at once and don't have to focus on one square to recognize the number. Maybe moving to the savanna required our ancestors to also develop a longer range focus in their vision, since they had to look for threats all the way to the horizon not just in their immediate surrounding like in forest canopies. When combined with the abstract thought bestowed by language it would allow them to gage distance to a threat, giving room to ponder on their action.

Language is also a very power thing I'm by no means assuming I know more then Dr. Matsuzawa. It actually reminds me of stories I've seen of people born both blind and death; upon learning brail their cognitive development skyrockets since they now have a framework for abstract thought and the potential for an internal monolog. From my very VERY limited knowledge of the human brain it seems the areas for vision and language are quite close. Perhaps when our ancestors Parietal lobe (language center) developed it squished down the occipital lobe (vision) as well as the temporal lobe (short term memory). I'm of course just thinking out loud and these are simply ideas with little substance but food for thought.
The thing is, how do chimpanzees even know numbers?

You know, if you look at something and quickly close your eyes, a picture of what you were just looking at stays in your head for a second or so and you can continue to look at it. Try this with a ceiling fan that is spinning. Look at it, close your eyes fast as if you're blinking but do not reopen the eyes, and you'll be able to count the number of blades the fan has because you'll have a still image of what you were just looking at that remains.

one thing i dont understand about the theory is relation of language to short term term memory.

Their short term memory is fantastic and better than human's. And it makes sense as the Professor said "They look in the bush and spot and remember 1,2,3,4,5,6,7 enemies.

While humans have long term memory and future memory, and imagination that could be stronger. But id be curious how to test long term memory, future memory, and imagination in chimps.

I dont see the correlation of language to short term memory. They are very different things.

Id argue for animals living more in the moment. Where they spend far less or very little time thinking of the far past or distant future like we do. But there is memory. The monkeys remember how the games work, remember different trails in the forest and where the best fruit trees are. Same for dogs and remembering training and commands.

And thinking of the near future could be seen in hunters. Like lions, hyenas and even chimps too. In planning and coordinating with others. You go here, i go there, he goes here, and pounce at the same time.

But there doesnt seem to be evidence of them thinking about the far future like we do. we worry about things years away. Jobs, career, having grandkids or kids one day. Do animals? Do apes?

and that might account for their short term memory being stronger. They like many other animals "LIVE IN THE MOMENT" Where as humans find ourselves stuck thinking of the past or future more than the current moment at times.

I dont see the correlation of short term memory and language though, Id argue there must be rudimentary language for chimps. Mainly for present moment or near future. "Snake, danger!" and for basic hunting and planning evident by collaboration between the members, and by using rudimentary tools like stones to open coconuts and sticks to dig into termite mines indicating some degree of planning.

Just my thoughts

Micheal vs Younger Chimp in Memory Challenge = Me vs My Son in Rubix Cube Challenge

I taught myself the basic algorithms once, solved a cube once with the aid of a video and tried to show my son....he couldn't care less. then, years later, he decided "yeah, I want to learn this but on my own". 🤷‍♂️👍👌 whatever it takes, so long as you are learning what you want to learn.

I told him what a speed cube was and....that was that. it's been almost 3 months and he can sole a 3x3 cube in under 30 seconds. I know: the world record is much faster.....but you take three months, try to live the social life of a 12 year old who turned 13 during those three months....and see if, at the end, you are ready for school, handling your social life, learning new tricks on your scooter, learning how to ride skateboard, learning how to fish (from rigging up poles to dealing with bird nests to learning to cast accurately with a spincast)......and at the end of that 3 month period, let's see how fast you've gotten your cube time down to. 😜😄

It is shocking to me that the most astonishing aspect of this experiment is not that the chimp has a better memory than the human, but rather the fact that the chimp understands what each of the numbers mean so that they have to be touched in a  serial numerical progression. That astonishing ability seems to be accepted rather matter-of-factly by Dr Matsuzawa. And  in cases where not all nine numerals are used, like  "1 ... 4... 7..." the chimp still understands that she must touch the numbers in ascending order of their numerical value. I have known for decades that chimps could interpret symbols or sign language to represent tangible objects and actions, but this is the first time I have seen a chimp that grasps the concept of numbers representing an order of actions. Since chimps are anatomically incapable of speaking, I would contend that there really is no "cognitive tradeoff" between chimps and humans. The chimps are at least  just as "smart" as the humans, given a particular task that does not require spoken words.

Putting Michael in front of that machine for a short time, is not a representation of his capacity to learn how to do this. Necessity is the mother of invention, or in this case, adaptation. It had four different colored buttons, and to start, Simon would start playing a repeating pattern, first one of the lights would go on, and the player would have a short time to press the colored button that had been lit. Then it would add one more, and the player would have to accurately repeat the pattern. Simon would keep repeating the sequence, adding one more each time, and the player had to keep up. Creation was the engine that drove our physical and cultural evolution into a previously unoccupied niche in the environment — survival by outthinking the predators. Very interesting. We see other evolutionary trade-offs in nature, so this makes sense. The brain can only process so much and language to ensure communication/co-operation between early hominids and their descendents seems a very fair trade-off for decreased short-term memory. After all, those have contributed to our past, present, and future survival.

I wonder if we can ever accurately assess the intelligence of non-human animals, because we don't speak their languages. Of, course it's not language as we understand it, but they do have grunts, calls, barks, etc. that are a form of communication. It's impossible to know if they can express abstract thinking, but there has been no evidence that we can see that they can. It would seem that only we and our cousins, the Neandertals had/have that ability. I have a theory that animals are as intelligent as they need to be to survive in their environment. We have lost some of the ability to utilize short-term memory to the extent that chimps can (witness Michael vs. the chimpanzee), but we have evolved the ability to live in large complex groups, something chimps don't need to do since their local societies are much smaller and less complex. Maybe they've never lost acute short-term memory because that is important to their survival and we have because we need other skills like the ability to communicate/co-operate with other humans and to express complex concepts and abstract thoughts.

The CHLCA are a very interesting species to study as what happened with them, I.E. some of them taking the ground while others remained in the trees. MIrrors what is likely to have happened 300 million years ago when, due to some reason, two groups of animals diverged away from reptiles. Some learned to use burrows to live in and would eventually become mammals, while others moved upwards into the trees to nest and would eventually evolve into avians (birds). One group, the mammals would develop a full emotional empathic response in order to allow for the parenting behavior and as a consequence of this develop social behavior. The other group would develop only a limited kind of emotional empathy (avians) that would allow for flocking(social) behavior but only a short parenting period ending with baby bird being pushed out of the nest to either fly or die.

Since empathy promoted social behavior is can easily be imagined that vocalizations evolved as an extension of this system. Allowing individuals to better express their current emotional state. And so we come to your tradeoff with humans developing full blown speech presumably to further enhance this behavior. With speech, as you say, we became able to tell stories. To have a sense of time. In other words to think in abstract terms. Thus we have the evolutionary pressure needed to develop our next innovation, cognitive empathy. With cognitive empathy we are able to 'put ourselves into another shoes' so to speak. This too is a highly abstract way of thinking. If it seems hard to conceptualize then think on this challenge. Try to get your dog to understand that you want to take them to the park. But not today, not until tomorrow. Try as they might, this concept will be beyond your pets ability to conceptualize. And so with cognitive empathy we then see how and why we have developed hyper intellect.

And so it went from reptiles to mammals with emotional empathy. To vocalizations to better express that empathy. To language that still further enhanced said empathic ability. To cognitive empathy that introduced us to abstract thought. And abstract thought leading us to our hyper intellect. The ways in which your presentation meshes with this theory I think genuinely gives both of these a high likelihood of being factual at the end of the day.

Actually cognitive tradeoff is common in evolution. The key lies in how the brain is organized, not how big it is. Brains evolve just as bodies do. If our environment changed dramatically, no doubt our brains would change, too, and the survivors would be those whose brains functioned best in that new environment. We see similar brain differentiation in other members of the animal kingdom. In this case, the chimps retained or acquired a higher facility for rapid spatial memory, but sacrificed development of that part of the brain that enables speech.

A similar tradeoff probably accounts for human evolution, too. Neanderthals and Homo sapiens had brains largely the same size, but it is probable they were organized very differently. Neanderthals survived in Ice Age Europe for hundred of thousands of years before we arrived and adapted to a specialized hunting lifestyle (attacking large mammals from ambush) that put a premium on sight, hearing, touch, and smell and a brain that could process those stimuli rapidly. But they were not notably innovative (they largely used the same stone tools they brought with them from Africa eons before) and they lived in small, isolated clans and were not social. They had the brain of a predator. Homo sapiens also began with simple stone tools, but soon developed a far more sophisticated tool kit, built large social networks and traded for goods, hunted in organized groups, and shared food in hard times -- indicating their brains were wired a bit differently from Neanderthals from the start. This began a feed back loop between intelligence, tool innovation, language, and improved diet (from more successful hunting) which led to an intellectual and cultural explosion about 50,000 years ago that elevated homo sapiens from mere hominid to humanity. Forty percent of our total caloric intake today is used by the brain, for thinking and communicating. We are predominantly social creatures.

We cannot analyze the brains of Neanderthals and early man directly; brains do not fossilize. But we can trace the difference by examining what each did. From the neck down, Neanderthals were not that different from us, but when the climate in Europe changed 50,000 years ago, Neanderthals lacked the ability to adapt mentally and went extinct. Given the rapid techological advances of humans today, it seems likely our brains in the future will be wired very differently and that some people alive today would be unable to function in that future environment and will have no representatives alive one million years from now. Or it may be that higher intelligence is itself an evolutionary dead-end and that our ability to create weapons and machines we lack the judgment to use wisely will ultimately lead to our own extinction. Evolution has no meaning and no destination. All scenarios are possible.

So it's an interesting theory, not sure if I believe it. I think Chimpanzees have better photographic memories in order to travel in dense jungle, as everything would look the same without it. However their memories in general aren't any better than humans. You could tell Matsuzawa was getting incredibly annoyed when Michael was beating Ai. Even when Michael was doing well on Ayumu's 9-digit test, Matsuzawa had to exaggerate on the difference in time completion - even though he was the one who told Michael to keep going slower.

Ayumu is clearly doing something incredible regardless, but keep in mind - this is a chimp who has been trained for YEARS from birth. If any person took this type of test for an hour, they would immediately be better the next day. You can train your memory to excell in certain testing conditions, and this is no doubt what is contributing to Ayumu's speed. They seem to use the same clip of a few rounds of this memory-game to display how good this chimp is at it, but my assumption is that this was a selected run of several games the filmed with the best display. I bet you if you had the monkey video taped at random, his error rate would be MUCH higher.

I believe they do have innate abilities that make their memories better with spatial sense, shapes, etc., yet likely exaggerated. You may ask, why would they do that? It's a very common problem in science. Just like Matsuzawa, most scientific studies, and all larger scale ones like this, are gov't or industry funded. If the studies aren't producing data and information that is worth it, funding will be dropped. Then everyone will be out of a job. This is literally the backbone of scientific study, it all hangs on whether you can or cannot get funding. This has led many shady people with fantastical theories supported by shallow evidence to get grants/funding over scientists who truly want to find answers.

The prostituting of science is a widespread problem, much larger than most think. Many scientists won't speak out against it either for it could hurt their chances of funding in the future. I've seen the manipulation of data for monetary gain before, and I immediately got the same vibe from Matsuzawa. That doesn't make him a bad person by any means. Many of these scientists just get tunnel-focus on a theory, and cannot bring themselves to accepting other possibilities because of how long they've been chasing one theory. Even if it is entirely funding-based - it's just human nature.

Ayumu is not remembering different numbers (always 1 - 9), but recognizes where the same numbers have moved spatially each turn, recalling long enough to tap on them in the same learned sequence of 1 - 9.  So it is not just accurate recall, but fast recognition of the position of numbers (0.5 seconds).  If you are swinging about in a 3 dimensional environment and trying not to fall to your death, a quick recognition and accurate recall for the position of things would be a good.

Regarding the theory that the stronger chimpanzees forced us out of the trees:
I read about another theory for why we do not live in the trees anymore in "Why we sleep" (Walker, 2017): We fell off during sleep. This is related to REM sleep, which is very pronounced in humans and which makes our bodies limb (otherwise we would start acting out our dreams). Once the body is relaxed in such a way, it is much more likely to drop down. Therefore, we have decided that a bed on the ground is a better idea.

Actually I'm not so sure what might have come first: REM sleep that made us sleep on the ground, or us sleeping on the ground that has in turn allowed REM sleep to develop. Probably the two aspects have reinforced each other. In any case, the interesting thing is for me that REM sleep is said to be closely related to our creative abilities and abstract thinking capacities. If the REM sleep of a chimp could be enhanced, it would be interesting to see what happens. Would it start to perform worse on the memorizing test from the video? Would it gain other abilities?

As far as.primates go, I think chimps are actually the dumbest of all. Even at full maturity, their brain don't even develope to the size of a 3 or 4yr old human child. Sure, they can be taught to do things, but usually and only because the task itself is usually a repetitive one in its normal course of use, like combing your hair or bouncing a ball. So they're just mimicking it, which gives the appearance of learning, but they can't expand or evolve on it. True learning, as with humans, provokes the desire to perfect or improve on most tasks, either for necessity, or the natural instinct to be better or more efficient.  This requires things like reason, logic or aptitude.  Very basic and natural skills that even a small child has. Chimps have none of these traits, and often get frustrated, impatient, and easily agitated. It's why they usually attack or kill what they don't understand!

Humans can train short time memory. There is a lot of research on that and even some "apps" that actually work. Unless the Kyoto team did the Bayesian thing and actually tried the reverse by training humans, that theory is complete bullshit. It only shows that a "flatter" memory system is faster... which is a given fact by design.
Evolution of language did require change in the memory design for humans and yes that design is slower(comparatively, not effectively) in direct access to simpler designs. Usually because it involves a lot of extra analysis and meta connections required by abstractions like language..
Point is if you have trained humans compete with the chimps they will likely match. If you have highly trained chimps and humans chimps will win again, bun only on certain small dataset sizes. It's the same with AI systems. Humans have(physically) many times the number of cognitive connections in the brain primates have. They are just not trained that way. In fact some humans with autism that develop different brain utilization patterns show that clearly. They can have massive photographic memory capacity, precisely because they have happened to train their brain that way due to their condition and circumstance. In fact there is research that shows autism is exactly that loss(partial) of abstraction capability in brain functions.
So that's a valuable research, but crap of a theory.

To remember those 9 numbers by the chimps is impressive but I wonder why "only" 9 numbers and not, let's say, twelve (to say a higher one) or many more.
I don't think a chimp needed to count how many enemies there were in a place, but to know how many different species there were and how they were laying-out on the scene. Some of them can be a threat, some others not. That would be what make them to distinguish the numbers (all of them meaning different species) and where they are allocated in the space before them. It's not easy to find more than 9 species in one place all together, so their brain wouldn't need to memorize more than that number o one slightly lower.
Another better (IMHO) possibility is that that ability is needed to recognize quickly the different members in the group, because some of them have a predominant role and one doesn't have to disturb them and they can even be a threat. Especially if you're a young chimpanzee, you're probably at the lowest of the group, so you must remember more members not to annoy them. If you are an older chimp, the ones that are in a higher level are likely less, and so your memory can free some neurons for other tasks.

Chimps evolved in a three-dimensional space with short ranged visibility where elements of their surroundings need to be evaluated as quickly as possible in all possible directions, predators, preys, the next branch to swing from... Whereas humans evolved on a two-dimentional plane that need a better evaluation of long distances in order to travel and to aim while throwing accurately. This in turn caused the evolution of the spoken language by necessity to explain to others how to navigate in a forward manner on a 2D plane, which correlates to our grammar that is unidirectional, past->present->future, I came from there->I am here now->I am going there.
Indeed, language took the place short term memory occupied in our brains, but it didn't happen as a direct consequence of us needing to learn how to cooperate to protect our children because we were weak, as Pr. Matsuzawa seem to suggest, but rather as a byproduct of our new and different way of navigating and evolving through space, long term memory of large terrains and a way to transmit those memories precisely being MUCH more useful in great plains and savanna than short term memory and a quick 3D evalution of space while moving.
Fun fact, you'll see that dogs, who arguably evolved the same way as us on large scale 2D terrains respond way better than chimps to the dimentional indicators we use, such as pointing.

I was able to follow the numbers as fast as the chimp, It's called minimizing subvocalization. It's the same technique I use to read a paragraph, or even a page at a glance.
- Humans can do it, We just end up tripping over our own brain, As we process the information. Speed reading techniques are about training your brain to stop processing the information linguistically, Stop using Subvocalization. In way you do it all the time, Like this.
- It deosn't mttaer in waht oredr the ltteers in a wrod are, the olny iprmoetnt tihng is taht the frist and lsat ltteer be at the rghit pclae. The rset can be a toatl mses and you can sitll raed it wouthit porbelm. Tihs is bcuseae the huamn mnid deos not raed ervey lteter by istlef, but the wrod as a wlohe.
- Human beings are capable of processing vast amounts of information like you might have just did when reading that sentence. In the same way you see a word, & process it. You can take in an entire paragraph, Called Chunk reading. & still process that information. So long as you train youself to stop subvocalizing.
- In essence, Language does trip us up. But we can do the same thing these chimps are doing by retraining our minds to stop tripping over the process of sub vocalization.
- Think about it this way, when playing a video game. for those of us who game. You enter The Alpha, & Beta waves in your brain shift. Spacial Reasoning processes much quicker than linguistic socialization. It's an association game. When you shift from association, to muscle memory, The results can be boggling. Watching someone type at 70 words per minute. Or a person play one of those twitch reflex games. The brain can accomplish amazing feats of processing power. Associative cognizance tends to cross wires, & slow that down.

1. Mr. Matsuzawa mentioned our ancestors being weaker and through a series of events they had to develop language to share. "Complex language". I'm not sure we can really claim any sort of superiority in that regard, when we don't fully understand the other "more simple" languages. A better question might be, why do we consider our communication so advanced, when the Universe is constantly humming with communication all around us we cannot perceive without assistance, and which we don't understand in any meaningful way when we do. In some ways, our communication and intellect are precisely what prohibit us from understanding more.

Anyway, there is evidence that behaviors of chimps and other higher order mammals are evolving behaviors which we can observe in the very short span of time we have been measuring and observing them in a scientific way. There is a pack of chimpanzees which rule an unprecedented amount of forest. They were documented because they also exhibit behavior which is extraordinarily violent and calculating in its cruelty, with the specific intent of increasing their numbers and territory. It's fascinating, but also difficult to watch because it sort of mirrors the more violent and ambitious behaviors of various periods in our early history, where barbarism and cruelty very closely mirrored the violence and ferocity of our primate cousins. In some ways, we prove that becoming more intelligent doesn't necessarily go hand in hand with moving away from some of our more animalistic and feral instincts.

My theory, is that developing complex languages required losing good short term memory, because language is most useful when people have long term memories about what other humans told them. Having more energy put into long term memories meant losing energy put into short term memories. And so, as these traits evolved dramatically, humans just got so good at remembering language and what people told them, that they didn’t really have a need for that much short term memory anymore. Remember these changes happen over thousands of years

And what about crows, dolphins, elephants, and other social creatures that have clearly developed types of language that convey events through time and indirect experience? A PBS Nature documentary about crows had a particularly awesome study showing that a learned "scary mask" was passed between generations without the second generation ever actually being exposed to the mask, they still gave the same response they were "told" about by the previous generation. (A Murder of Crows)

There are two questions involved: 1. How can a chimpanzee understand the numeral symbols and their sequence (e.g. 1 goes before 2?) 2. Are these abilities are natural to chimps rather than a result of being trained over a period of time? These two questions lead to my assumption that human being can perform to this excellency if trained. So it fails to prove the tradeoff hypothesis.

Very interesting episode. Two personal experience notes:

1. I’m actually very good at the visual memory and it took me ironically a long time to develop language and I did it differently and as I understand other people do it. I don’t think in language. So this fits with what you were talking about.

2. I farm and I work with livestock guardian herding dogs and we have about 300 words of language that we use between us. I get the sense that they have a bout 1000 more words that they use between themselves. They string words together in sentences on occasion although normally they only use one or two words at a time. They definitely have nouns verbs adverbs adjectives and names for both individuals and classes. They also do basic math involving counting addition and subtraction. All of these skills fit with the work that they do. The last note on them is that these are actually 87% wolf so they’re not your average dog. I’ve been working with them for about 30 years.

The most obvious problem is that the chimps have years of training in this kind of task, while Michael has none. Hey Michael,
I have pretty bad ophidiophobia (fear of snakes), and seeing even an image of a snake, much less an animation of one lunging at the camera, can cause vivid and uncontrollable trains of thought and if seen at night, severe insomnia. Ophidiophobia is the most common phobia worldwide (Vsause 2 even did a video on the universality of fearing snakes) and you may want to be mindful of putting such vivid images in your videos. I hope this doesn't come across as too sensitive--pictures of snakes are everywhere on the internet (even when you google "phobia of snakes," ironically) and they really do have a strong effect on people like me so I'm trying to give feedback where I can. Love your content, keep up the good work!

This isn't that good. If you haven't watched yet, here's what it says: chimps have a surprisingly better short-term visual memory than us. This is possibly because as we were forced onto the savanna, cognitive functions such as speaking became more important, thus more of the brains mass was given over to them. The only practical example offered by the researcher is that chimps need to make very quick decisions such as to determine how many enemies are nearby, which apparently became less important for humans because the savanna was so safe.
That's it. The rest is repetition, Michael doing worse at the chimps' more difficult tests than the chimps do, a bit more fluffy editorialising, aaaaaaand 24 minutes is up. Watch if you want but it doesn't go near as deep as other Vsauce vids I've seen.

USSR ANTHEM STARTS PLAYING

All animals share a very similar brain that responds the same way to the same chemicals and neuro signals, we are part of the great ape family. All animals (including ourselves) have thoughts and feelings and in fact have the same emotions.

Anyone who has had a pet can do a simple demonstration. When your cat or dog come up to to be pet they are doing two things: 1. They are coming to you, not your sofa, not the table, not anything else, they go to you. They have remembered that you pet them and when they want to be pet again they know to come to you. They are to distinguish between you and everything else. This demonstrates thought. 2. When your pet gets the pet they wanted they perform a response or pleasure, and when they get pet the wrong way they perform a response of discomfort. This demonstrates that they can feel.

Why can't we "listen" to what animals have to say when they communicate? Well, you can and you can't. All things communicate uses their senses, it what senses they use to communicate that can differ. When it comes to mammals the majority communicate using primarily visually and secondarily tactilely and tertiarily verbally. It is not to say that don't use their other senses to gather information, they just don't use those senses to express information. Perhaps you are thinking you have seen your dog sniff to gather information before. What they are doing if sniffing for pheromones, which humans do the same thing after shaking hands but this isn't the same thing as expressing information. It is not common to see a communication model not like the one mentioned previously in mammals but some mammals, such as humans do. Humans flip what most mammals do and communicate primarily verbally and secondarily visually and tactilely.

Your communication model is something  are born with and language is something you learn. Language is based on communication models, so all human languages you learn with primarily involve verbal components. Usually we don't involve visual communication in our language but rather use the same visual communication across our species and call this body language (which is a poor term as it isn't a language). There are some visual languages (such a sign language) but all of those languages are based upon the use of verbal language and translating that into hand singles or otherwise to express thoughts in the same way you do verbal language, i.e. words. Because some visual languages exist, we can and have taught other animals how to "speak" our visual languages, such as Koko the gorilla. We have a hard time learning other species visual languages because unlike ours they don't base their visual languages in a verbal or word like way.

Can other species that share the same communication models communicate with one another. Yes, but not completely. While latin isn't a communication model but rather a language we can latin demonstrate a point. There are languages called romance languages with are based upon latin: spanish, french, portuguese, italian, romanian, etc. While all of the romance languages are different languages, because they are based on the same language they can use those different languages to express thought amongst themselves without having to know the other language but have difficulty expressing increasing complex ideas. Different species that share the same communication model have developed their own languages based on the same model and can express ideas amongst each other but the more complex the idea the harder it is to express it. Just like we can express ideas in english to someone who only understands japanese by using on simple level, but when we share the same language we express even more complex ideas.

Why this is important when it come to autistic people is understanding our communication differences. Through my own understanding and experiences with communication as well as speaking to other autistic people it is my understanding that perhaps our communication model is much like other mammals being primarily visual and secondary tactilely and tertiarily verbally. Having a different communication model could explain our communication differences and sharing the same communication model as most mammals could explain we understand other mammals a lot more easily.

When thinking about how I express emotions, my emotes are not naturally my face (a demonstration of primarily using verbal communication up close as having facial emotes aids in verbal communication in a close range to demonstrate subtlety of language) but rather my stims using the rest body. Emoting with your body is something allistic people do to a degree but not much as their face, much like my primary emotes being with my body but there a few natural emotes with my face such as smiling when in uncomfortable situations (which other primates also use to demonstrate aggression and ward off others) but there a few stims I also do using my face but not as many.

I had to learn to use my face to emote and it always feels forced and unnatural, but my resting face makes people think I'm upset or angry. People can't ever tell what I'm feeling because they look at my face, which gives no information, and when they look at my body they see some information but miss alot, alot of the information they see is variables they recognize but those variables don't usually mean the same thing. I feel like only ever being taught to recognize emotions in ways unnatural to how I emote, such as any emphasis on the face and what little emphasis on the body not being the same, has contributed to my alexithymia and I have been trying to work out when I'm not making how I naturally emote and what feelings that is tied to like: more vigorous movement means the feeling is more intense, joy is pressing my feet into the ground, excitement is bouncing, happy is swaying my hips like a cat does before they pounce, comfort is bringing and pressing my arms to my chest, sad curling up, anxiety is shrinking my body, feeling shame is when I try to hide any expression but end up curling some and trying to cover my hands near my chest (which I think is a mix of sadness and seeking comfort), rocking I think is seeking comfort when anxious and sad rather then when I seek comfort by pressing my arms to chest and shrinking when anxious but not sad, on edge is when my body is more open and I am making eye contact kinda like how people are taught when relaxed people look like but for me it my body getting and being prepared for attack or getting attacked and the eye contact is what can set off that reflex and so can sudden movements or anything shady and I tend to think of it like a cat's stalking reflex for hunting or any combat they are prepping for, but these are just all the things I've pinpointed but not necessarily every emote or feeling I do just what I recognize and can attach something to.

The way we as autistics understand and express communication naturally is fundamentally different from allistics. Allistics have a model of communication that is primarily verbal and secondarily visual, all languages come from this model and even languages such as sign language is based on that model. There is some universal body language, such as smiling and crying, but the more complex emotions are the more body language becomes cultural. Autistics have a flipped model, or rather we share a model that most of the animal kingdom uses. Our model is primarily visual and secondary verbal. I remember growing up not understanding verbal communication at all, I just mimicked sound patterns that produced different results for me and just made the noises I thought everyone else wanted to hear. When I was 12 I learned that using those kind of scripts doesn't always work and was trying to figure out how people communicated and how to learn to both allistic communication model but also english on my own for the next 6 years before I began to understand it. Nearly all autistics are partially verbal, some completely nonverbal even. Verbal communication is not natural for us and some of us pick it up better than others.

When we talk about fight or flight, we tend to focus on 2-3 of the 5 options people make that there is: fight, flight/run, freeze, but there is also posturing and submitting. Posturing is given the signal either verbally or nonverbally you are a threat, it is primarily a means of being dominant and aggressive, and from my experience allistics find social (as opposed to physical as in a fighting context) posturing to be arms crossed, not looking towards them, and not verbally communicating as much but what is strange is that is exactly what I do when I feel comfortable and relaxed when engaging verbally with someone. For me, posturing in a fighting context is body facing the person and and giving eye contact, in essence what allistic people seem to want for relaxed and comfortable communication. When someone is making eye contact or facing their body towards me like that my instincts feel they are posturing for a fight and the emotional pain associated with that is what I feel, and that pain can turn physically and more aggressive when someone wants to come closer and comfort in an allistic style when I am acting on instinct alone. When talking to my fiance about our instinctual responses and feeling something we are learning is that there are shared physical actions, of which physical actions variables, and variables that aren't shared at all (like her facial emotes and my body emotes). Those variables have a function (what they serve to display or feel) but a lot the time shared variables have a different function and shared functions have a different variable. It can cause a lot of miscommunication.

That's the thing: humans aren't necessarily *smarter*, but we are more linguistically inclined. This is an important distinction, as this one factor explains everything about our perceived intellectual superiority over other animals. Sure, we probably are more intelligence than many animals, but in others we probably are not.

Take an uneducated chimp and an uneducated human, both of which have no cultural knowledge. The chimp wins on a base level. Every time. Yet once you add even a bit of language into the picture, of passed down cultural knowedge, then we have an immense advantage. One where the more collectively intelligent we get, the more intelligent individuals are. All because of language.

I realize the idea is to challenge Michael in the same way the chimps are challenged... hence the numbers, but Chimps (given they're lack of things like language) may not necessarily recognize numbers as numbers - and probably don't think of them as being in any sequence other than the random patten they are shown in/trained to recognize, where as humans do. Subconsciously a human is probably more likely to think of numbers in the 'correct way' - following some form of logical sequence (like numerical or multiplicative). To more accurately test the hypothesis, and get results more representative of the true difference in short term memory between the two subjects they should have used new and unfamiliar characters/symbols.


I have no doubt that Ayumu would still be able to outperform Michael, but making the chimp feel equally as unfamiliar and uncertain as the human would have been the true test.


EDIT: I realize they weren't going to program an entirely new test just for the sake of this episode, I was only sharing my H Y P O T H E S I S : )

For chimps, numbers are just pictures.
And humans already have that ability.
It has nothing to do with language.

It's the same principle that we can remember the picture by watching 'mona lisa' for only 0.1 second.
We don't memorize pictures.
We only remember the image we saw with our eyes.

The chimp does not memorize the numbers, but just looks at the picture and memorizes the visual information in the image form.

Humans can also restore that ability through some practice.

If evolution is the course people use to explain these apes, they have already started off on the wrong theory. Evolution is not an actual thing, adaptation is not evolution. There is no missing link for humans because we are the link. Apes are still apes after millions of years, humans are still humans after millions of years. Evolution explains that animals started as another type of animal and changed into what they are today over the course of those millions of years. This is impossible. Adaptation Is what causes changes in a species. A bird in the jungle is very bright and colorful by comparison to a desert bird. Why, because of adaptation not evolution. Take a liger or tigon. Two cats that have no way to make babies naturally. It has to be done in a lad. Why because a tiger and a lion, while both big cats are fundamentally not the same species, yet polar bears and Grizzlies can breed naturally because they are the same species with separate adaptations. A grizzly is colored and built for the woods where a polar bear is colored and built for icy climates. This is the biggest example of adaptation vs. Evolution.

I’d like to see this test done with people just coming home from combat.
I think the key to this is the ability to see the whole screen as one object. Humans have the habit of focusing on a single object in the field of vision. So when the jimp (lol)
Looks at he he sees all the numbers and the pattern. Where humans focus on the numbers in sequence 1.2.3.4 ect. Thus in .05 sec. time you only see 1-3 numbers.
Soldiers returning from combat often have “the 1,000 yard stare “ this is a defense mechanism of the brain. You stop focusing on single objects ,and instead take in the entire picture we see. It stores that image and allows us to pick out any discrepancies or movement.

For example, this year I taught in kindergarten 2 children English who were likely to be autistic*: these children were incapable to have conversations beyond set of learned phrases repeated daily and while they rarely seemed to pay attention to lessons and did not respond to rewards, when it came to testing vord recognition (point to the picture, join picture and word) and spelling, they always had the highest scores. What if children and/or adolescents and/or young adults of various ages were to be put in a similar situation and given this task?

Also, what if these human subjects were given mental focus training, using meditation, etc.?

It would be interesting to see how much better they might do. They may not do quite as well as the chimps, but it would be interesting & enlightening to see just how well they could do, in light of neuroplasticity.

I’m about to get nerdy on y’all.
So in the interview, they emphasized that monkeys are able to make mental snapshots to then make quick decisions. Then, humans are worse at creating mental snapshots at the expense of language. HOWEVER, I have been studying human behavior and conducting research. There is something notable about human mental snapshots.
Humans are able to distinguish if a person is trustworthy, friendly, and likable in only 80 milliseconds, and sometimes less- at distance of 300 feet.
Again, humans are able to decide if people are TRUSTWORTHY with 70% accuracy in under one second, even if that person is 300 feet away. Our mental snapshots (“first impressions”) have evolved in a way that is beneficial to us.
A photographic short term memory would not be as beneficial to humans as being able to determine if a person is a friend or foe by decoding body language in under a second.

My question is how does this hypothesis explain the OODA loop training given to soldiers who are taught to d precisely these quick memory tasks. (OODA - Orient, observe, decide, act.) Obviously the soldier who can complete the loop faster lives longer, hence the training...not that this is relevant to the question. What is relevant is that these soldiers do not lose language skills even as they gain situational awareness skills. Does the OODA process - being conscious - use a different area of the memory circuits in the brain?

Also in reference to autism and verbal skills: I am a thrice diagnosed Asperger's autist and a published writer. This apparent paradox has led me to doing quite a bit of research and I discovered that there really is a spectrum of autism here just as in every other task set. There are some like me who are considered hyperverbal so I don't think the cognitive tradeoff hypothesis applies to autists the way it does to lower simians. Looks like a spurious correlation. Something else is probably going on in our neurodiverse minds.

Monkeys (typically) - Shorter legs, longer arms. Better for swinging, better at quadrupedal movement.

Humans - Longer legs, shorter arms. Better for carrying, better at bipedal movement.

This is why I hate when people teach "functional movement" and emphasize how a monkey of some kind moves. It doesn't necessarily work like that. Their feet work like hands, their hands are much bigger, longer and stronger. They can brace themselves with their hands for balance when squatting and support more of their weight where as we support all of our weight with our leg muscles when squatting. It's simply not the same.

I think what happens with the 0.5 second test is that, as humans we've learned to look for patterns and then act on those patterns. If we see numbers like 1,2,5,8,15 etc increasing in a linear pattern , we look for the 1, then the 2, then the 5, 8, 15 etc. Which is just too little time to first read, look for pattern and then make a decision.

This is what probably helped us understand patterns like the rain water cycle and helped us use it to farm instead of forage, or use the patterns of rivers flowing to use the energy it creates for ourselves, or even the patterns that we had to learn about wild animals, their hunting/sleeping times etc and how to avoid them because we're physical inferior.

I think in that particular test if they could get a child , or any person who doesn't know how to read, and put them through the same drill , it could have interesting results. Maybe put them through the same learning protocol of numbers as they did with the chimps and go from there.

Or train an adult to not look for a pattern, not see numbers and just see the board as is, with shapes, and then remember what they've seen.

I think it could help with understanding how adaptable we are as a species , and how our brains can relearn to make quick decisions to take up a task. Heck take it a step further and put the human and chimp in a sort of CT scan (or whatever scan) to see what part of the brain is working for that given task.

Regardless this was super interesting.

I was one of the few people to have had a photographic memory as a child, I still remember what it felt like. I've done some interesting things, including theorizing (correctly) about black holes at the age of 7 and learning the whole multiplication table at 6. My first words were at round 6 months and I could convey messages in convoluted mixtures of fictitious words soon after. My mom told me I made up words for things I hadn't heard of when I first tried to hold conversation, some of these words stuck till kindergarten. I wonder how Prairie Dogs fit into this hypothesis. Because they have been thought of as nothing but pests, there hasn't been much study of them, until recently. Some researchers think that they posses language skills second only to humans. They clearly work together and have assigned tasks--watch how they deal with a snake that enters their territory. The glaring problem is that they theory of human "intelligence" rests on our (limited) capacity for conscious thought.  The same (short-term memory/working memory) tasks that we now know that chimps perform better than humans at, are in theory, to account for individual differences in human intelligence.  But then psychology doesn't care to explain the obvious fact that chimps are not demonstrability smarter than humans.  It should be clear that intelligence proper takes more than what is tapped into by conventional IQ tests, which seem more glorified short-term memory tests.

No.


Genetic variation has to randomly increase, and persist, before its products can thereafter find some advantageous application. Many other species could have developed 'cognitive brains' but either they could not acquire the initial surplus of energy required to permit their inherent variation to support ordinarily lethal 'smarter brains' or, if they somehow did acquire it, they used that extra energy on run-away, and ultimately lethal, reproduction.


Somehow one species of primate (pre-human) managed to suddenly and uniquely acquire an excess of energy (food) per person to support all types of random variation and, just as importantly, not turn that excess of energy into an unsustainable population explosion. Thereafter, when conditions tightened, those with big brains suddenly had an advantage.

Interesting hypothesis, though I am skeptical. Think of it in positional and strict-order tasks. Those two particular tasks are commonly seen in FTP mobile games, and would likely give a similar dose happy neurotransmitters. I would put money on it, that humans, (given the same amount of practice of a similarly difficult task) would outdo their ancestral cousins. The food reward system only serves as point of interest. I'd argue that, given the research, this only shows that humans can shift their experiences of time from long term to similarly "in the moment", while chimps are exclusively in the moment. Interesting social dynamic in Japan. I wonder how it would pan out in different cultures.

Mind you, I'm a strict non-believer when it comes to making hypothesis. Cultural sway, personal gains, and issues with funding have all cheapened the good intentions of the hypothesis. People, and their intentions to prove, are by far the messiest parts of science.

something i am considering is that maybe the reason humans are worse at the number task






because we know what the numbers are and when we see the numbers, we need to take that extra split second to decode the symbols in our minds and translate them into the numbers and count from 1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8 9




while the chimps do not know what numbers are. they are not "counting". they merely learned to recognize the symbols and what order to push those symbols in, and that enables them to make the decision more quickly, because their brains don't take that extra split second to decode the symbols, it just reacts.




which, I guess, "could" validate the bigger theory. i suppose. because it's our tendency to use language and use those symbols to represent language which is causing us to pause and try to translate it while the chimp doesn't recognize it in the same sense, the chimp just reacts to the symbols.






perhaps a better way to test us vs the chimps would be to train the chimps with symbols that are not associated with language and then train a human with those same symbols.
but then again, the human might still make names for the symbols in their mind and that would ultimately slow the human down because they would then start translating the symbols into whatever words they made for those symbols while the chimp is just reacting.

1. While it is entertaining to watch, we gain very little insight into relative cognitive limits from a middle-aged human on basically their first try performing less well in a task than a young chimp with likely many thousand hours of training. (I do not doubt that chimps are way better, but this is not good evidence.) 2. That we have an ability chimps do not have (language) but perform less well on something else (short-term memory) is only weak evidence for us having traded one for the other. Humans and chimps differ in many ways, and we may well have traded for something completely different, or more likely a one-for-one exchange picture is simplistic. The mechanism proposed by the researcher also does not check out. While it is true that neighbouring brain tissue can be recruited by increased usage, there are language areas but there are no known "memory areas" in the brain. 3. To claim that the chimp ability of photographic memory of a static pattern helps for evaluating a situation with "nine enemies" is a stretch. It might rather help to remember the location of "nine ripe fruits". Indeed, I'm prepared to bet that humans are better at the former. Evidence? Well, watch some FPS gaming on youtube. There you have multiple enemies rapidly moving on complicated trajectories in a visually rich environment with a ton of distractors (including almost identically looking "friendlies"). Humans are great at dealing with such situations. Indeed, rather than having traded for language, humans might simply have adapted their cognitive abilities so as to be better hunters / warriors, as compared to the chimps likely optimising for gathering. 4. I note that we are now worrying about keeping the few remaining chimps alive, rather than vice versa. That really tells you all you need to know about the overall cognitive and social powers of these two species by the measures relevant to evolution.

Something I don’t get: That test with the chimpanzees literally didn’t allow you to physically see all of the numbrs there. Your eyes might have registered it via the light they’ve collected, but the brain wasn’t given enough time to physically process what was there. Memory deals with information already collected and processed. It's about information retention, not collection. Had we been able to have a few seconds to actually do this, then made to wait a short time before being tasked with disclosing this retained information, THEN it would be an accurate test of short-term memory. But it isn’t — instead it’s a test of the brain’s visual processing capabilities and reaction time.

It DOES make sense that humans would have reduced REACTION TIME in order to compensate for language, as the brain would need to wait a certain period of time to receive the necessary information from language, which is more complicated than the methods of communication employed by apes. Because it is more complicated, it is slower to input and output it from one person to another. It takes more time to speak than it does to use body language, and signs, simple screams and grunts, and pheromones, and it takes more time to process.

It will take you several seconds at least to read my passage before you comprehend it at all. For a chimp, it would be near instant for his eyes and brain to physically capture it all, but he wouldn’t of course have the faculties for processing comlex language other than simple words. Even if he did, he would start to read it and stop right at the very start because he'd react to the first few things you said and not listen to anything else. If you’ve ever come across someone who listened to some of what you tried to tell them and immediately jumped the gun and interupted you without listening to anything else, imagine that, but every single time. Right as you speak, the ape (assuming it has faculties for processing language and speech, and can talk on the level of a human. I know they already have limited faculties, but can only understand so many single words) immediately is done with the conversation because what little you say is enough for his brain to decide it has all the information it needs to respond.

Chimps seem to have a much faster processing ability because their methods of cummunication are much less complicated than language. They HAVE to be able to react in a split second to THEIR language. Not just their language, but the ability to move they way they do — swinging and climbing — so precisely, swiftly, and accurately. If we had their processing ability existing alonside our language and speech faculties, we’d have a lot of difficulty understanding our own speech, because the brain would be too busy processing sounds the moment they come out of the mouth rather than waiting to collect enough sounds to form coherent meaning like sentences and the meaning behind them. All we’d hear are words and sounds, becaue our brain would decide that this is enough information to act on.

Coreect me if I’m wrong, but I believe that the premise of the Cognitive Tradeoff Hypothesis is flawed — at least as far as short-term memory is involved. I thnk it is more accurate to describe cognitive information processing. I also don’t buy the claim that the ancestor of humans were “too weak” to stay in the trees and were kicked out. That just seems so self-deprecating and also doesn’t make any sense.

I think Dr. Matsuzawa's research is quite interesting, and his experimental setup is quite good. I am thoroughly impressed he developed a method of training chips to be able to develop cognitively and to demonstrate that development in a consistent, repeatable way. However what was shown here at best demonstrates consistency with the hypothesis, and nothing more. Michael's failure to reproduce Ayumi's speed at the game demonstrates nothing.


Chips are recognized as having impressive cognitive ability (at least within the animal kingdom). Dr. Matsuzawa's research demonstrates that chimp's can be effectively trained to perform tasks (to my knowledge this was already known and demonstrated, and not just for chimps!). Ayumi has been playing this game presumably since it was able to climb into the box along with its mother. This could be many months, to many years (exact age was not specified) of exposure to this training paradigm. During this time Ayumi started off slowly and with a low number of digits and then progressed to the blistering fast pace with a high number of digits. Given a chimp's aforementioned ability to respond to training, this should have been expected.


What should also have been expected, is Michael's inability to reproduce this precise end state ability (the speed and accuracy) his first time playing this game. It is not surprising that he was unable to match the speed or accuracy of the highest performing chimp, as he has undergone no training whatsoever. Additionally, there are signs he was progressing himself fairly quickly. His times generally were trending down, and his accuracy was trending up (he completed the last puzzle of the set, also in the fastest time). Again, not shocking as his repeated exposure to the tests were serving as training for the subsequent test.


I don't dismiss this research or its corresponding hypothesis in its entirety because I understand that it is possible in the associated publications they did comparative trials of one form or another (rates of learning, top end performance, etc.) showing chimps with equivalent training times as their human counterparts were consistently outperforming these humans. However I am being generous here because the claim/hypothesis, though intriguing and with evidence demonstrating consistency, is in my opinion not actually being tested with what was shown here; and hence I am speculating as to what else has been done that was not shown. Again, at best, this research presentation demonstrated that chimps can be trained (already known) and with that training they can out perform humans with no training (impressive but not all that unexpected). However without evidence showing humans can not perform at or above this level, with a corresponding amount of training time, I assert the hypothesis remains thoroughly untested.

If the chimp is trained in this from the start his brain may have favored more short therm working memory. It is well known the WM of humans is about 7.  The fact that the chimp gains food after doing it makes it so the brain reinforces the recognition of these exact patterns. If the old chimp would have beat him after some training that would be solid evidence. What's next? Parrots beating people in memory tasks because they were trained from birth? The theory is solid, but the idea that WMC was just shrunk for exactly language is a bit far fetched. A simpler explanation would be that the optimum for survival is just big enough for 7.

Great insights.  However, Dr. Matsuzawa may have overlooked what is possibly the most important function of imagination.  Sharing is one product of the ability to think abstractly -- imagination -- but perhaps a more important outcome of imagination is creativity.  Creativity, the ability to see two things, or concepts, or possibilities in our environment and make an entirely new thing/concept/possibility.  That ability to create seems to be entirely separate from "intelligence", whatever that is.  Dolphins have intelligence, but don't ceate.  Creativity churns out things like stone tools, agriculture, counting, symbolic reasoning, language -- everything that makes culture.

Those plastic shields are not properly sized for longer human limb bones. This impedes impulsive brain moments, and reroutes some brain time to making arms drive carefully around traffic barriers. The impulsive, and the flashed visual memory, these signals degrade and decay in those micro moments. Remove the barrier for humans, give them fruit rewards, and redo the experiment.
I know the chimp is using only one arm, but the human should use two. It doubles the memory map power in that each arm can recall just some of the numbers, and the left vs right impulse is another layer of usable mental code, another data bit.

As modern math humans, we see those digits as small equations, we try to understand their value and source.  The chimp just sees different bugs.  Imagine if we are like the chimp on the savannah, and see enemies, we size it up right away as how big the bugs are and how many.  Modern human would be puzzling the lineage of the enemy animals, whether they are a protected species, did they, or we, do their proper taxes this year, etc.?  In that time of rumbling in our mental attics, the enemy has vanished, or is already eating our young.

I don't agree with a trade off. I think this is a change in how memories are made. When there are less interpretations of an event it is easier to remember/organize. The brain doesn't make memories arbitrarily. You barely remember unimportant things or dreams. It's just the cost of semantics - not real estate.

Did most of the people in the comments miss the parts where Matsuzawa said the research was still young and that his idea of the language-memory trade-off was only a theory and not fact? He was never making bold claims, and the research has to happen slowly in order to be accurate. He hasn't always had the opportunity to study these magnificent creatures in this kind of pseudo-open environment. Yes any one can become great at the pattern, but there's a threshold/plateau of learning involved. He's interested in that threshold, and that takes time, and also takes willing participants -- hence the optionality of it.

I am thinking that the chimps are not counting the numbers up, though they can obviously put them in chronological order. I think they are more recognizing the numbers, and remembering which order they go in. There does not seem to be any link between the actual written number and the representation of that number, eg, they are not counting the number of enemies in front of them, as Tetsuro hints. If they are taught to always press the picture of the apple, then the tree, then boat, then the rock, they can remember the correct order of those objects.

A similar effect happens to people that are either blind or deaf for a large portion of their life.

It's just the limitations of our eyes, not our brains, that is making a STUPID test like this extremely difficult to train for.

Without actual neuroimaging data to support his claim that there is a negative correlation between memory and language centers in the brain, I just can’t buy that hypothesis. There are seemingly countless reasons as to why these chimps are successful at this task, which is inherently an operant task (a simple Stimulus-Response-Outcome task... they even pair conditioned auditory cues (both CS+ and CS-) with the outcome, which is known to facilitate reward-seeking behavior in rodents. This task is a reward-seeking task). It’s important to note that with any animal behavior, the incentive salience of the reward has a very powerful influence over learning and subsequent performance on the task. Sweet treats are a very salient to a chimp (more so than for a human subject), and they probably have extensive experience with this task.

The idea that chimps have some “super memory”, and that we as humans have given up some of this ability to be able to perform other more complex cognitive tasks, is an interesting idea, but this experiment is insufficient evidence on its own to form such a conclusion.
