Do chimpanzees have better spatial working memory
than humans? In a highly publicized study, a juvenile
chimpanzee, Ayumu, performed substantially better than
university students on memory for digits displayed for
210 msec in a spatial array (Inoue & Matsuzawa, 2007).
The authors further observed that Ayumu could pause
several seconds before responding—for example, in re action to environmental sounds—and still maintain high
performance. The authors described these abilities as “ex traordinary” and likened them to eidetic (so-called “pho tographic”) memory. The findings were reported by The
New York Times, the BBC, NPR, and all four U.S. televi sion networks, as well as in the pages of Science.
However, Ayumu was the only 1 of 6 chimpanzees to
achieve this level of performance. Furthermore, Inoue and
Matusawa gave their 6 chimpanzees extensive training
on a non-time-pressured version of the task, wherein the
digits did not disappear until the subject touched the first
digit. Training involved approximately 200 trials per day,
5 or 6 days a week, and began in 2005. At the time the ar ticle was published in 2007, 5 of the 6 chimpanzees (those
other than Ayumu) were still being trained. From this, we
can infer that training was quite extensive. In contrast, the
human subjects received almost no practice of any sort.
In a subsequent study, Silberberg and Kearns (2009)
showed that humans can match Ayumu’s performance
when they get extensive time-pressured practice—that is,
practice at the extremely short 210-msec stimulus duration
that was used for the final test. This finding, while casting
some doubt on the conclusions of Inoue and Ma tsuzawa,
does not decisively overturn them. It is perhaps unsurpris ing that human performance improved for the 210-msec
task after practice on the exact same task. In contrast, Ayu mu’s success occurred with no prior practice at 210 msec.
Instead, Ayumu’s practice sessions allowed the animal to
observe the display at leisure until initiating the response.
Inoue and Matsuzawa reported that the average latency be fore responding was 650 msec—far greater than the expo sure time used by Silberberg and Kearns for practice. Thus,
parallel performance in humans and chimpanzees under
comparable conditions has not yet been demonstrated.
In the present article, we report that, with practice simi lar to that undertaken by Ayumu, our human subjects not
only matched but outperformed Ayumu. Furthermore,
human subjects can maintain high performance with short
delays, demonstrating an ability similar to that reported
for Ayumu. Finally, a pattern mask disrupted performance,
suggesting that facility in this task is supported by ordinary
processes of iconic memory storage or retinal afterimage.
In sum, there is no evidence for a superior or qualitatively
different spatial memory system in chimpanzees.

Because who needs memories when you can write things down or tell your buddy. Also if everyone is working together to look out for the group, there is less of a need for the individual to react instantaneously.

There is nothing else on a Chimps mind but “I am hungry” “do the task” “get the food” with less going on, fewer distractions of conscience there is nothing but focus on these three things. Not impressed. We often have people who try to compare human thought, memory, stimulus response time, etc to primates, birds, dolphins, all in a attempt to magnify animal behavior and belittle human behavior. Yes, its an impressive trick...but think of Annie Oakly...if all you ever had to do was walk around and shoot things then shooting coins tossed in the air is no big deal. But give the same gun to another human being with different experienced and they will fail. A young human mind is the best for learning as there are no cognitive distractions in their conscience and they have untrained neural pathways. Once you put them into an educational system be it mental or physical these pathways are established well used and behavioral performance of either physical or mental tasks becomes specialized. A chimps hard wire is hunger, how to get food? Of course they will become specialized at how to get food in their environment. Look at primates that learn to use tools...it is always and only how to get food that drives them...or an itch you just can’t reach to scratch.  Cuttlefish and their understanding of spatial orientation, deception, and future planning is far more impressive as it occurs naturally in their environment, but the key is  they want to get food from their environment. Necessity is the mother of invention.

I see one issue when comparing human to chimpanzee in the task presented in your video. As you said chimpanzees are taught from young age how to do the number task to get their reward and they start from easiest level successively progressing to harder ones. @Vsauce, you did compete against Ayumu but you had no, or little previous experience in this particular task. Ayumu on the other hand was doing it since he was very young. He wasn't that good from the start. Basically it was like putting a rookie against a champion.

So basically what I wanted to say is that in order to make this hypothesis more convincing you need to have a human that is practicing same task over and over again and then compare him to Ayumu. Otherwise you won't have eliminated a possibility that a human could reach same level of mastery and perform equally well (as we know human brain is subject to neuroplasticity and can achieve many great things once trained).

Other thing that came to my mind would be to have a savant with very good memory make this task and see his result and then maybe compare some parts of his brain with Ayumu to try to track down if similar parts of the brain were more developed to do this task. Not sure about how this one could contribute to this hypothesis though.

BTW: I love monkeys and admire the habitat prof. Matsuzawa and Kyoto University created in Inuyama. Hope I will have a chance to visit it one day.

This Cognitive Tradeoff Hypothesis has been rejected long time ago since its method of experiment is invalid and wrong,. I dont know why Michael is giving it attention... Ayumu was the only 1 of 6 chimpanzees to achieve this level of performance. Furthermore, these 6 chimpanzees were extensive training on a non-time-pressured version of the task, wherein the digits did not disappear until the subject touched the first digit. Training involved approximately 200 trials per day, 5 or 6 days a week, and began in 2005.
At the time Tetsuro Matsuzawa published his article in 2007, 5 of the 6 chimpanzees (those other than Ayumu) were still being trained. From this, we can infer that training was quite extensive. In contrast, the human subjects received almost no practice of any sort.
In a subsequent study, by Silberberg and Kearns, they showed that humans can match Ayumu’s performance when they get extensive time-pressured practice —that is, practice at the extremely short 210-msec stimulus duration that was used for the final test.

It's not JUST language. Our words depend on making a wider set of associations, through a net of synapses, than just a narrow few. If we connected with just a few neurons for each word, we could do it much faster but it would limit the accuracy and complexity and interrelatedness of our concepts; but it's not JUST words.
Our curiously-shaped ears with that folded bank of sound reflectors also collect more different analytical reflections of sound than other animals. If our ears were simple parabolic dish reflectors like those of a cat or a fox, we'd hear small sounds much more accurately, and faster - without needing time to analyse. Our hearing gives us more information about direction and the sound properties, but it takes longer.
That's the common theme: think slower, but deeper. That's intelligence. Words, I suspect, follow later, but become such a valuable by-product that they enable man to reach the technological dominance we now hold.

Taking the chimp tests was cool. The tasks seemed relatively trivial compared to the effort Michael was putting in though.

I know part of that is that I'm relaxing on my couch and he's sitting on the floor of a chimpanzee box.

But I think a big part of this is also just what skills we use. We don't generally have a need for this skill in our world. I play a lot of games like untanglers and puzzles that aren't that different. Whether that has nurtured different brain structures, or if I have different skills, I think Michael's admission from season 2 that he "hasn't played video games in years" might impact his performance.

I think our intuition tells us that we need to encode the numbers and the order in a pretty straight forward way. Like a passcode for our phones.

However, our brains are really good at building maps and processing both 2D and 3D space. If instead of trying to memorize the map, you instead create a geometric shape that correlates to the pattern, you should be able to encode the information much more quickly and retain it for much longer.

This would not be dissimilar to the changes Michael saw in the Video Game Pathfinding episode from Season 2, where he switched from memorizing the maze layout itself to a series of landmarks and hallways shapes. It is likely the same process, but more abstract.

All of that said... 0.5 seconds is bloody fast. You go Ayumi!

It would probably be more fair to compare Michael's first attempts at the trial to the chimps' first attempts at the trial and see who is better. But that then becomes more of a question of who learns faster. The best test would be if Michael did this task for a while, like over the span of weeks and then tested his speed. I have to disagree with two points of Matsuzawa's hypothesis.

Instead of being 'kicked out' of the treetops by the CHCLAs thereby creating circumstances under which the cognitive tradeoff became necessary; perhaps the cognitive tradeoff made it harder or impossible for us to navigate the treetop swinging from branch to branch and tree to tree?

Losing the ability to mentally process rapidly changing and complicated visual input, such as quickly moving through tree branches, would make if difficult to compete. Or even survive in such an environment.

Also, I don't think a tradeoff is necessarily due to limited capacity. While the ability to develop language may have come from genetic mutation, that mutation could have included the loss of the cognitive abilities.

So perhaps one of the first things they expressed with their newly invented language was "guys, I keep swinging into tree trunks and it's starting to hurt. I'm gonna try my luck on the ground."

I speak 4 languages and have worked as a translator for a few years in my home country (Haiti) when I was 21 years old. Once there was this (interactive) conference where I was the only translator for a group of 10 English speaking foreigners. I got to a point where I was talking nonstop, with no understanding whatsoever of what I was saying in any language, yet everyone understood me and were actively taking notes. I got worried and interrupted the whole thing a few times to check that things were being conveyed clearly enough. I guess what I am saying is that I believe our cognitive ability to process complex ideas can be dialed down in favor of performance with a bit of practice. We get in the zone.

Divine intervention or genetic manipulation by extraterrestrials are not necessary to explain the expansion of the human brain. It is easily explained by a stage in evolution between the tree-dwelling ape and the savannah hunter, when the forest dried up and apes who lived along the seashore survived by venturing into the water, learning to eat shellfish and eggs of seabirds, both of which were easy to catch, and developing an upright body to keep our heads above water as we waded out in search of seafood.  We have a subcutaneous fat layer possessed by no other primates, but present in all aquatic mammals like seals, whales and dolphins.  This serves for  insulation and buoyancy.   The Aquatic Ape theory of human evolution also explains the enigma of the fat baby.  Compared to other primate infants, human babies are born round faced and chubby, in spite of the difficulty for the pregnant mother of getting enough extra calories to put fat on the baby, as well as the burden of carrying that heavy baby around once it’s born.  The only animals that benefit from a lot of body fat are those that spend a lot of time in water.  Fat babies float!  Sea mammals like dolphins and seals, as well as humans  have a subcutaneous fat layer that provides buoyancy, insulation and streamlining, needed for an aquatic lifestyle.  The fish, shellfish and eggs of seabirds provided an abundant source of omega-3 fatty acids needed for the substrate-driven expansion of our brains. Aquatic ape theory, also called “Seashore Man” also explains why we became the naked ape.  For swimmers, fur is a drag!  In order to dive after shellfish we needed to learn to hold our breath. This was a prerequisite for the development of speech.  No other land mammals are capable of controlling their breath.  For more information on this fascinating theory see the works of Elaine Morgan, including a TED talk.

The hypothesis is very nice but full of holes. I'll explain a couple that I know of and give an interesting paradox as-well
First of all the evidence, while I havn't looked into this theory very much, this specific piece of evidence isn't evidence at all. These chimps live in this enclosure, and this task is made to simulate a foraging task. Something modern day humans do not have to do. So everyone understands lets look at this like playing a video game, someone who plays the same game for years will obviously be better than someone playing it their first time. I use to visit my grandmother every now and then, she had an old mario game she liked. It took her 3 hours to beat the game (More than 60 levels) It took me 3 hours to get past lvl 3. It's obvious that the apes playing the same games over and over would get good at them. They can memorize 9 symbols in order in half a second. What about a human comparison? We have professional video game players now. These video game players can press on average more than 240 keys a second in an exact order with over 90% accuracy (I'm actually being pretty lenient here). That equates to over 120 keys every half second. Now this isn't exactly the same as short term memory, but what I'm saying is that if you preform any task enough then you will get very good at it. This is how our brain is built. Which takes me to the neurological side of things, with a few years experience and studying neurology I feel very comfortable with this explanation. Now when a specific part of the brain is used it tends to grow larger, when it's not used it grows shorter, and one part of the brain can take over functions to a lesser degree that use to be held by a functioning region that is damaged. Short term memory is localized in the prefrontal cortex, which in humans makes up 1/3rd of our total brain mass, and is four times larger than in apes. So the loss of one region of the brain for another is completely ridiculous considering that the very region we're talking about is much larger in humans than in apes. Now if we consider photographic memory, that might be a different story, that would be located in the visual cortex, which is larger in apes than in humans. However this still does not support the theory because as he mentioned it would only make sense if the regions gained and lost are very close to one another. The prefrontal cortex is the front most part of the brain the visual cortex is in the back most part of the brain, literally the furthest that they could be apart in terms of distance. Now, there are other minor reasons that poke holes in this theory but I'm not going to go into those because my comment is already large enough.
Lets get onto the paradox then, any creationist readers will probably like this one.
A study preformed to measure the brain mass, activity, and etc of many animals that can use tools found that it should be impossible for any creature to have evolved to the point at which they could use fire as a tool without first having fire as a tool.
A simple explanation, the intelligence of any creature is determined not by the size of the brain but the number of specialized neurons, specialized being a key word here. We can measure the number of specialized neurons in the brain, we can also look at fMRI images to determine where tool use is localized in the brain and measure the number of neurons in that region of the brain. We can then measure the energy needed to maintain and use that part of the brain on a regular basis, and we can compare that energy to the maximum amount of energy that can be obtained from the environment. What was discovered is that tool use seems to be broken down into the number of steps required to preform the tool use. Simple tool use takes one step. Complex tool use is three or more steps. I'll break this down more, take cracking nuts for example first you have to find a nut, then find a large rock, then place the nut on the rock, then find another suitable rock, then slam the two rocks together over the nut. That's five steps. This is simplified obviously. few creatures can use tools with this complexity, namely great apes and humans. These two creatures obviously have the most number of neurons in the animal kingdom and require similar energy consumption. In humans our brain consumes approximately 1/3rd of the the total energy our body consumes every day. In apes I believe the number is about 1/4rth. Our brain contains about twice as many neurons on average than the average ape brain. But I'm getting off topic here, basically after doing various measurements and years of study across more than 50 tool using species the scientists theorized that humans would have had to have fire (Which multiplies the amount of energy we can obtain from food) for at-least 400,000 years before we could have evolved to the point at which we could create and use fire as a tool. Now obviously there are many many theories trying to explain this, but all of them fall short. The best one is a mathematical theory that simplifies the equation, but even that only half's the amount of time needed to evolve fire as a tool. Now when I say use it as a tool, I don't just mean create it and carry it around I mean actually cooking food, which is many many many steps Just think about cooking a marshmellow, you have to find the food, find the stick do a strength test and length test put it on the stick hover it over the fire, do a distance check so its not too close not too far (this check is two steps) then watch it and do a cook test to determine when its cooked (several more steps) then take it off the flame, let it cool, etc... This simple explanation is at least 11 steps, and that's not even including making the fire and determining what food can and cant be cooked and etc.
Anyway this is the human evolution fire paradox, I thought some people might be interested in this. I'm not trying to disprove evolution here just stating a simple paradox, if I tried to disprove evolution I would have written a much, much, larger and more detailed comment, but I don't like typing that much, so yeah.

Fascinating, I love this! It's interesting to think that we may have given up part of our short-term memory in order to develop language and imagination. Animals have limited imagination whereas humans probably have the most imagination. It's kind of ironic though, you know? Because another hypothesis says that part of the reason we don't remember anything from when we're really little is because we haven't developed language yet. Once we begin understanding language and speaking, our memories (at least, our explicit memories) improve. So I wonder how that works, exactly. If language is necessary to develop memory, but we gave up part of our memory in order to speak, how does that work? Perhaps because language is necessary to develop long-term memory, while short-term and implicit memory doesn't require language. So while chimps have incredible short-term memory, they probably can't recall things like from when they were young and vice versa for humans, we have great long-term memories and can recall things from childhood but our short-term memories don't even compare to a chimp's.

I'm not so sure about this. There's the implication (and apparently this is what happened) that the chimps start off easy and eventually work their way up to the harder tests. They don't just start on the hard test right off and magically ace it. This seems to be nothing more than standard trial and error training, where a person (or chimp) gets better at a task over time, and eventually gets to a point that when viewed out of context seems "super human".

The 9 digit test may be on the upper end for performance, but I see no reason that a human wouldn't be able to do that if they did this task daily like the chimps do. Maybe even do better, if you had several humans doing the tests and they could communicate discoveries and oddities of the test with one another ("the numbers always ascend in a spiral," perhaps). Also, don't have the humans getting mesmerized by social media and videos and such throughout their day, but just chilling in a nice, safe habitat with natural lighting and you'll get better performance out of them as well.

I just find this to be dubious. Chimps definitely have us outclassed when it comes to strength. As for memory, I think their advantage there (if it exists) is one of environment and not biology.

EDIT: After all, Michael was attempting to compete with the best performing chimp, but only in the span of a couple hours. How long did it take Ayumi to get to his level of proficiency? Probably more than a day or two, I would surmise.

But is this a skill that we can learn?...Or not? Its not impossible for humans to read as fast as Ayumu or Ai. In this long comment let's see how it's possible. The chimpanzees aren't reading the numbers, but they are looking at a giant picture instead. Imagine a painting of a horse in the foreground, mountains in the background and a hay field in between. Now if you focus your eyes only on the horse you might not be able to see what else is in the picture because you are so focused on just the horse. In order for you to see the mountains your eyeballs have to shift to that portion of the painting. However, if you focus on the whole picture you would be able to see all elements of the painting. This is essentially what the chimpanzee is doing. He is looking and the entire screen at once, instead of looking at the individual numbers and shifting his eyes between the digits that are presented to him. We humans can also do this, albeit with practice. The reason why we have to practice this in order to achieve it is because of the way we learned language or more specifically how to read. Typically when someone reads something they have a voice in their head "saying" the word they see. If they don't have that mental voice in their head then they use their actual voice while they read. Ask yourself this: are you vocalizing right now? There is a third way of how people read and that is; to read without a voice. It's really hard if you've learned to read the traditional way, but doable.The theory behind how chimpanzee reading or speed reading is simple. It takes time to say a word in your head or by voice. When you read a word out loud and you hear it, that's when you know or understand what you've read. For example lets look at the process of how vocal readers read; upon the first word reaching your eyeballs the brain recognizes it and looks it up in it's database., once it finds a match, your brain then signals your mouth to move your lips to sound out the word, then your ears have to hear what you've said send it back to the brain for a final confirmation, and that's when it registers. Now that sounds like a lot of steps. Compare that long string of processes to the one speed readers (readers who don't utilize a voice either mental or physical) your brain sees the word, then recognize it. That's right. Just those two steps. See how much faster that is? Now combine this with the idea of expanding your field of vision with your peripherals. You should be able to see many things across a large screen and recognize the whole picture and one. For instance lets say you were reading a book. A normal person could read a single page in about 1 minute or less. A speed reader however can read the same page in 15 seconds or less because instead of vocalizing each word has they read, focusing sentence by sentence, a speed reader is reading paragraph by paragraph. Fun fact Teddy Roosevelt was known to read a few books a day because he could speed read (more or less.) If you want to get into speed reading there are many resources to learn how, one of the easiest way to do so is by using the app "Speed Reading" by Speed Reading Team. You can find the app online at speedreadingteam.com Happy reading and happy holidays! ( I am in no way affiliated with the app, I just use it and know it's a great way to get started.)

Michael doesn't owe you anything. I totally get missing his old style videos, but Mind Field is incredibly interesting and fascinating. He gets to experience, learn, and show us things he could never do without a company backing him. Yes, this does mean that there's only one bunch of uploads each year and a majority of the videos will be for Premium members only, and unfortunately, that's not for everybody. Vsauce2 and Vsauce3 both upload high quality free content with Vsauce3 matching YouTube Premium quality FOR FREE on a consistent basis, and Michael still makes videos for DONG on the side. He also convinced YouTube to put Episode 4 out for free when it releases and he is finishing up a regular Vsauce video right now. Michael never stopped working or doing what he loved. The way we consume it is now different. And it's not like YouTube Premium is some kind of evil entity that must be stopped because it's "destroying YouTube." If anything, it's helping to legitimize YouTube as a platform where a creative person with a passion for something can be as respected as a mainstream celebrity. Jake, Logan, Viners, etc. are more at risk of destroying YouTube - heck include PewDiePie in that list, if you feel like it, as his carelessness on a few occasions has brought a lot of heat to the platform. What I'm trying to stay is: Don't complain that "you're not getting the real Michael" or "the old Vsauce" or "it's sad he locks his videos behind a paywall." He is getting the opportunity to teach us and show us ideas and topics that he never would have otherwise, he stands as a shining example of why YouTubers deserve all credit they earn and the respect to be taken seriously as creators, and he still delivers regular content on the side. I would say that anyone who refuses to at least acknowledge this lacks respect for Michael and what he does as a creator and should rightfully be ignored.

This is coming from someone who is not subscribed to YouTube Premium, btw. I understand being upset or missing Vsauce content, but there comes a point when there's a real lack of understanding and respect for the amount of work that goes into producing something like this. People other than Michael worked on this show, you know, and the minute Mind Field stops being profitable, they'll drop it. Don't assume you know what will happen if this series was gone and be careful for what you wish for, but, more than anything, don't disrespect Michael or the team that worked on Mind Field. This is pure speculation but could it be that the way in which we use our working memory be another variable as to why we cannot do the task as quickly as the chimps? When i look at the numbers i as do all humans use my auditory monologue to encode the data into my executive functioning memory. While this is our primary way to remember things for us, it does take longer as we must internally go one, two three, four etc in order to have it in our working memory. Of course we would then keep it in our memory using rehearsal which i believe the monkey would not have as a function. As we have an inherent meaning behind the numbers it may be limiting for us to view the them as just the visual  form thereby taking us longer. It would be interesting to take this test as not numbers but as a form of different visual shapes which might not be so entrenched into our auditory monologue and this might force the human to only use iconic memory.

In Frans de Waal's latest book, 'Are We Smart Enough to Know How Smart Animals Are', he writes a bit about how many in the scientific community reacted negatively to Ayumu's memory feat.

In the context of the book, (at least the first half), Frans is using this as an example of how limited we have been in defining and testing intelligence. In fact, he points out it was Japanese researchers who first introduced an empathetic viewpoint to studying Chimpanzees (omoiyari?).

I am still in the process of reading the book, and I'm not sure if Frans is going to pursue the direction of the Cognitive Tradeoff Hypothesis, but as an applied linguist myself (and in Japanese colleges for the last 35 years), this theory sounds entirely plausible.

One possible weak point of the theory though, is how, or if, it accounts for 'dark triad' personality traits among humans — machiavellian opportunists, narcissists, and psychopaths. But then again, chimpanzees also appear to have individually distinct temperaments, so we can presume not all of those temperaments are as 'loving' as that of bonobos.

Combined with Dunbar's Number regarding cognitive constraints on social connections (and by implication, rule-driven hierarchies rather than empathy-driven communities), there are all kinds of implications regarding the moral (or immoral) nature of what it means to be a member of homo sapiens.

p.s. Just finished Fran's book (the 3rd I've read from him), and confirmed that he is the researcher I would choose as 'Would Most Love to Chat over Beer With' award. He did not go into the Cognitive Tradeoff Hypothesis (for which I am grateful for this video), and I think he oversimplified Dunbar's hypothesis by implying Dunbar was referring to overall brain size (rather than just the pre-frontal cortex) and cognitive limits to sociality.

But Frans did a fantastic job of pointing out something I see in many of the comments to this video. A large proportion of humanity can seem to justify self-worth and identify only through an 'othering' process, rather than a connecting process.

My guess is that there is a genetically influenced temperamental trait among homo sapiens, stronger in some more than others, which predispose such people to egocentric exceptionalism, and no amount of reason or education will change their fundamental assumptions.

But along with Frans' book, the limits of language and logic (Wittgenstein and Gödel as modern examples, Lao Tzu and animistic/shamanistic traditions as historic antecedents) also seem to indicate that the entitled, egoistic temperament is just as likely to be found among those who fetishize science as among religious zealots — a lot of secular Japan and China being prime examples of some of the uglier, economic forms of fundamentalist self-interest.

As implied above, it is not just the moral implications of this video that are intriguing. Far Eastern cultures such as Japan, Korea, and China stress the importance of rote-memorization, especially for high-stakes, standardized tests for college entrance exams (the Centa-Shiken in Japan, the Gao Kao in China). It is interesting from an anthropological viewpoint how an emphasis on rote memorization may affect cultural norms and political dynamics as well.

But in the long run, I can't help but to feel a bit pessimistic.

Both good science and self-interest dictates that we SHOULD compare humans with chimpanzees (and bonobos) as a fellow 'social' primates.

But where among the chimps and bonobos can we find populations exceeding small communities — our own tribes becoming large scale 'herding' primates, and then self-destructive 'swarming' primates?

When the populations become too large for mutual recognition, communities are replaced by institutions run by the double-edged sword of hierarchies ... both 'binding' and 'marginalizing'. But hierarchies are based on rules that can, and will be gamed, rather than immediate empathy.

No matter the institution ... political, economic, religious, education, etc ... 'meritocracy' is little more than a carrot (or whip) to keep the majority in line, while the entitled minority tend to be self-entitled, despite rules — not because of them.

This is where I am pessimistic about our long term sustainability. We may have already passed our tipping point of survival as a species.

About short time memory. Is it the same or is it different form "working memory"? People with attention deficit disorders (ADHD; SCT aka ADD) have troubles with working memory. And it seems, like hunters-gatherers and nomads predominantly had attention deficit "disorders", which obviously were not disorders back then, as ~90% of modern day nomads are like that. Yet then people turned to farming, and now only ~1,5% (in Near East) to 4% (in modern Western countries) have ADHD instead of those past day 90%, so most people have pretty decent working memory, while,, obvisously, not as fast as chimps, but definitely better than guys with ADHD.
So... Are most modern humans going back a little in their evolutionary history, getting back a bit loser to other apes compared to where we where before people settled down and started farming?
P.S. But only in this regard, as modern humans are good at team work.

Perhaps the difference doesn't just lie in the shortterm attention/imagination tradeoff hypothesis when it pertains to this game, what if it lies in the differences between human/chimp visual processing? What if a chimps visual field is perceived at low resolution across the entire field of vision (dispersed equally between central and peripheral vision) and humans have high resolution central vision and low resolution peripheral vision? I noticed that, as I was playing along with Michael, I was darting my eyes across the screen (placing my central, focal vision on each number), and there just wasn't enough time to do that when they were on screen for only .5 seconds (but I could still remember what I HAD looked at). Maybe the reason chimps are better is partially because they can process the ENTIRE screen (and thus register the contents of the screen) because they're not "limited" by an enhanced central field of vision? It's the same thing on brain games, where they had the animals go on stage during the performance, and no one saw them because they were outside their field of PERCEPTION. Perhaps that contributes to the discrepancy of human and chimp scores? It'd be interesting to put this to the test by monitoring the gaze of chimps and humans performing this game (to see if chimps take the entire screen in at once and if humans bounce their gaze between each number.?

Not necessarily the correct direction to go! To say the chimp has better short term memory is to assume that the way our minds use VISION is the same. It does make sense that memory may have been changed to allow us to speak; HOWEVER, It could be NON GENETIC. EXPLANATION: If you are a reader...you MUST focus on each word one line at a time. it is nearly impossible to read all words on a normal page simultaneously. but the chimp is not trained to focus on one character at a time, then compute it's meaning in combination with other characters in some arrangement of proximity close by....humans are taught that ....therefore we do NOT excel at the task of looking at a tree with fruit in it and counting how many there were, colors, sizes, shapes. CONCLUSION: it may not be the cognitive ability to "REMEMBER" but the cognitive habit of "USING OUR EYES" To focus strongly on each character that slows us down. Harold

The scientific study mentioned in the beginning of this video has to be viewed in a broader aspect. What the researchers did was train the chimpanzees for many days and compared their testscores to those of humans who had no training at all. There have been follow-up studies addressing exactly this hypothesis where humans where trained to do this number-memory-task and they outperformed chimpanzees significantly. Looking at only one study could bring you to the comclusion above, but in science you never believe you are correct by having one shocking outcome, you repeat your experiment over and over, try to falsify it by (in this case) doing the same training procedure with humans. What is said in this video, is, unfortunately, untrue.

I think the most interesting thing here is how Michael was trying to solve the problems on screen. If you watch him, he is trying to plan the route his finger is going to take on the screen and memorize that instead of actually trying to memorize where the numbers actually are.

This is primarily why it takes him so much longer. The chimps aren't planning anything. They don't try to visualize in advance what they are going to do, they just get an imprint of the scene and mentally reference it when they touch the buttons.

Essentially they are using two completely different methods when trying to solve the problem, and the method that Michael is using is more suited to long term planning and repetition.

I would be interested in seeing what would happen if you gave both Michel and a chimp a set of 5 numbers to memorize and they had to get the right order 10 times in a row when only seeing the pattern once. Since Michel can plan his route, the more times he completes it, the faster he will get. My hypothesis is that the chimp will get worse as the memory starts to fade.

You can see a similar albeit small effect between modern humans.  Recent hunter-gatherer peoples, such as the Australian aboriginals, also score higher in spatial memory tests, and lower in language skills, compared to other groups.  They also live much more in the present, despite being quite capable of imaging the future.  The tradeoff is not just something that happened millions of years ago, but an ongoing process whenever the environment changes.

Pictures Vs logic.
My brother has dyslexia. He can spell some very difficult words that he has remembered.
I can ask, how do you spell: "Occupational Therapeutic Syndrome" And he'll get every letter correct.
BUT if I ask him to spell a word he has never ever seen before, the most shocking thing happens.
I ask, how do you spell: 'Descry' (a descriptive word meaning catch sight of). He will say: Z then A then U then any amount of jumbled letters for any length!

Dyslexic people do not form words by sounding them out, or using common association like SH has the letter S then H.
They look at EVERY single word as a picture! That's right, he cannot read or spell a single word. But he has memorized the squiggles (pictures of formed words) so perfectly that he knows ... I have no idea maybe 100s of thousands of words. He can read them write them down fully BUT he must learn the picture or look of the word first!

When I was a child helping him spell words, and still ignorant to his condition. I could not understand how he could spell Kite but when asked to spell say CAT, he would say: S then M then X then B ??? NONE of these letters are in cat! I would have accepted K, but not X!!!! It was the most strangest thing, that after he memorized the picture of the word he'd know it forever. Plus (I suppose due to this) his memory is incredible, my Mom has confirmed that some of his memories (in detail) at say 2 years old is precisely the scene at the time! I think my earliest memory is late 3yo of a single gate! He remembers the entire house, the plants, the color, and even a broken window!!!

My brother is truly amazing, sometimes I think he's a savant. But whilst growing up, many doctors have informed us he is merely dyslexic and has learned to memorize letters forming words, obviously lots of them!
I bet my brother could do this memory test a lot better than Vsauce did.

Edit// Spelling :)

EDIT 2// This must be said.
He's a logistics manager at one of the most leading international companies, a millionaire and owns (outright) 2 houses!!!!! Whereas I went to Uni, and I'm in absolute poverty and still renting. Pay day is today, that's good because I need some food, hanging out!!! Anyway that's our society, all good.

This doesn't really go into much detail. For example, if the numbers are colour-coded, does that affect performance? If so, that would indicate a difference in the ability to process shapes, rather than a difference in short-term memory.

And what if there are no numbers at all, just circles of different colours? Also, what if the numbers (or circles) are smaller and closer to the centre of the screen, does that affect performance? What about circles of slightly different sizes (where the subject needs to select them in order of size)? And what about arbitrary symbols that have no meaning for humans?

I'm sure the actual study is a lot more detailed, but the way it was presented here, it's more a party trick than science.

I have a couple problems with this theory.
First, I am not convinced chimps are better at this than humans. Ai lost to Michael. Sure, she was old, but she was also only doing 3 numbers and it was Michael's first time. I think there are plenty of people out there, who with enough training could do as well as an average chimp. They even say in the video they don't compete humans against chimps so how exactly do they rule out that we are not capable of the same performance?
Secondly, even if we believe that chimps have this ability and humans do not, this doesn't mean that our common ancestor had this ability. In the same way that humans are able to talk doesn't mean our common ancestor could talk, just because chimps have this memory ability doesn't mean our common ancestor did. This hypothesis that we lost this ability to gain speech is ridiculous because we have no reason to believe our ancestor had this ability in the first place.

These test results cannot be correct & here are few reasons why (in layman terms):
a) these chimps are trained & have become so good at taking these tests. If the human participant stays there long enough & gets the same amount of practice that the apes got, you can guess who will do better
b) the apes are provided food, water & shelter, so their mind can be free to focus on the task at hand
c) they are withheld food unless they perform, therefore they are conditioned to "think" that their survival depends on completing this task using classical conditioning techniques introduced by Skinner. In other words, they don't think they have a choice.

The short of it, this is nonsense & mere entertaining mainstream science! Do not believe even for a moment that the ape is smarter than you, or I'll personally visit you & slap some sense into your highly evolved, beautiful, but heavily misinformed head LOL

I think this video is really valuable because they figured out how to experiment with animals without hurting them. Their lives are still severely altered, but they've figured out how to prevent trauma. BRAVO!

But there is still something else inneresting going on here...

I wish V-Sauce would have shown us the expeiment and results then asked his YT Audience to think about why it is so in an Episode #1, Then return after 2 weeks with the Dr.'s theory. I think this would utilize human collective intelligence better.

Here's my thot:
The Dr. had them memorize an "ordered set". This is a very different thing than a non-ordered set. He could just as easily have had the chimp pick all the bananas out of a mixed field of fruits and nuts. His theory - idealistic as it is - doesn't explain why the chimp remembers things IN ORDER.

My guess is that remembering social hierarchy is super important when you are forced by circumstances to live in a group. Humans eventually found ways to survive as individuals. When we come into a space where there are multiple individuals, it takes quite a while for us to map out the pecking order. I think this may be why we have to construct such explicit social environments with labels and "positions" for individuals to occupy to make it easier for us to remember who we do or don't" have to" obey. I think this also explains why we have a vestgial memory of not needing this.

Isolation is an option for some of us. Not an option for most animals.

Development of language didn't happen for a bit after our ancestors left the trees.  There was a significant time period between leaving the trees and the expansion of brain capacity.  The reason we survived that period with so many physical detriments was because we stuck together in tribes.  And we stuck together in tribes because sex felt good and we didn't have a 'mating season' like practically every single other animal on the planet does.  We stayed in tribes to retain access to a group of sex partners for pleasure.  If females had not evolved to have hidden estrus, and we had not evolved to have the drive toward physical and sexual intimacy (something other animals have little need for), we almost certainly would have died off.  But because sex felt good and it motivated us to stick together, there were selection pressures that gave advantage to greater cognitive ability in order to navigate social interactions, which motivated development of language, etc and we were off to the races.  Don't sell sex for pleasure short.  If sex were mainly for reproduction in humans, nothing would make any sense.  It requires too much investment of time and energy, it is extremely inefficient (about 1 out of every 1000 sexual encounters results in a live birth, worst rate in the entire animal kingdom), and we have no way of knowing when it is even likely to work.  Burden any animal with that (without also giving it the drive to pleasure and social bonding) and they'd be extinct within a dozen generations.

I think loss of a short memory to speech is secondary cause. Let me explain myself: speech is heavily using same type of neurons as short memory. The synthesis of meaningful speech requires a lot of short memory - to convert current thoughts to sentence and relate it to the previous statement. The same is true for speech listening.
So, it is not coincidental that speech area created next to/in short memory area. As human language ability was growing, so the advantage of humans was growing too. And this new advantage made short memory less needed. So speech area indeed canibalized part of short memory but it happened because it was less needed anyway and canibalizing other areas was less beneficial. If short memory would be still in high demand, speech area would grow in some other direction, canibalizing other areas or increasing in size by itself. However it was not needed, giving away short memory was a "local minimum" for the least effort.

This Hypothesis is crap and based on so many false premises it is not even funny...

Premise:
Chimpanzees have better short-term memories...

Simply not true... even by the test standards of the program...
Best grown up Monkey (only learned the test as a grown up but with lots of experience) vs. Random grown up Man *(never played the test before)*...
Monkey 90%
Man 95%
Winner: Man

Conclusion Random unexperienced Man has better short-term memory than experienced grown up Monkey

Young Monkey (learned the test as a kid and has lots of experience) vs. Random grown up Man *(never played the test before)*...
Monkey: donno
Man: donno
Claim: Monkey did better (but without data to back it up)

Conclusion: Young experienced Monkey might be better

But... and the is a big BUTT*... try to think about something you as an adult only learned as an adult but most kids today have learned at an early age and grown up with... like computers... you give a random grown up *(with not much experience) and an experienced kid... some standard computer tasks and see who is fastest...
And I would be very surprised if the grown up won... just saying...

But what ever the result... the shown test results of the video in no way supports the conclusion drawn... that Monkeys have better short term memory (quite the contrary)... and when the premise falls the hypothesis falls...

So... the hypothesis: we gained language by sacrificing memory is BOLLOCKS (unless new evidence that can prove it arises)...

All the Clcas that decided to go down from the trees onto the savannah would have been killed by predators, having 'no sprint speed, natural offences or defences' or complex language system (yet). And there was not the necessary amount of time for favourable mutations to take place for them to have survived on the savannah because they would all have been killed by predators. How would they have developed a language system so quickly and to teach it to their offspring before being killed off?   If the chimp human ancestor who left the trees developed a complex language system within one generation (i.e. before they were all killed by predators) then we should be able to get chimps  to develop complex language. The best we have got is to teach apes sign language in California in the 60s and 70s .e,g. Koko. and there seems to be a limit with how much sign language they can learn. And we don't really know for 100percent certain how much the apes understand the sing language they are using. It requires heavy use of prompting, which was a big critique in the face of the Koko program, which still runs even though Koko died through the Koko foundation. If this is really true then it is possible for  chimps to develop complez language within their lifetime i.e. 40 years.  And I would be interested to see chimps being put in a position so as to be forced to develop those complez symbols of language first spoken then written. Great episode! The ability to speak has always been a fascination to me. Thanks to the evolution of our intricate linguistic structure, in part the FOXP2 gene, we have, what I call, the best defense mechanism possible. As for your ending note; since "being better" is subjective, I beg to differ and state that humans, able to conduct these studies, are indeed better off than those species unable to do so. Subjectively speaking because I truly admire wildlife as a whole. As for the study; Michael vs. Ai is obviously biased, but does kindle the question, "Can a trained human defeat a trained chimp in this game?"  I too dedicate myself to research. However, I use to dedicate myself to language interpretation. It is amazing how fast professional interpreters, not to be confused with translators, can do their job. An interpreter must identify the words spoken in the source language in its order, understand any colloquialisms, translate that to the different order of a target language to make sense, then ultimately interpret the conversation as fast as the other can speak! I highly respect and am amazed by Dr. Matsuzawa work. Looking forward to reading more of Dr. Matsuzawa's research and watching the rest of the series. Thanks, Vsauce! Thanks, Michael!

So... This was amazing. But I have a few questions:

1) how good could a human get with as much practice as the best chimp? Clearly Michael did not have that much practice and there's no way the chimp just came in and did as well as he is depicted in the documentary the first time he played; he had practice, a lot of it.

2) Is this really something that has been lost in evolution or is our conditioning as humans to blame? I.e. could we do something to improve our short term memory based on the theories underlying this phenomenon?

3) statistically speaking how do chimps stack up against humans in this sort of test? They admittedly pitted their best chimp against Michael. I'm certain that if we looked there would be a human that, with the same amount of practice, could beat this chimp. If this were true and this human could socialize normally it would seem their hypothesis is false or at least partly false.

I agree with the hypothesis, but I also see that the chimps are specialized to this activity and would perform well due to their daily use of the test to obtain the food. If a human performed this task daily from a young age, I would argue they could do much better than Michael and may be able to reach close to the ability of the apes. When Michael tried the hardest test, he did very poorly, however there is a key to winning this game that he didn't have the time to consider- if you look at the grouping of the numbers and the shapes they form, it is easier to memorize their positions than if you think of them as individual numbers in a sequence. Figuring out the sequence comes second to memorizing the shapes. Our mind thinks ahead to solving the puzzle while the ape merely sees the shapes formed by the clusters of numbers. You don't necessarily have to remember the individual numbers, you just use the process of elimination to work out the sequence based on the memorized shapes. I don't think a human adult could do this puzzle anywhere near the speed of the chimps, but if a human were specialized to the activity from a young age like the apes are, and could work out advanced techniques to solve the puzzle, they would be able to do it nearly as fast as the apes.

The human brain is divided in 3 basic parts (neuroscience is more complicated, this is just a simplified version):
- The reptillian brain (basic instincts, 'base consciousness', reactional thinking)
- The limbic brain (emotional/feeling brain, the part that processes emotions and makes us emphatise with other beings)
- The Neocortex (rational/thinking brain). Which has a left half (logical thinking, predominantly present in society -- a.k.a. the masculine part) and right half (creativity, the caring part -- a.k.a. feminine part).
The neocortex is what separates humans from animals as it is more developed, like planning for the future indeed. What if the true causes can be found within an imbalance between the left- and right part of the brain? Again, we live in a 'left-brain-society' which does not take hollistic thought into account.

What about the chimps being in their reptillian, reactional brain rather than the 'higher-consciousness' part because they're rewarded with food; correlating with one of their primal fears: the denial of food (hunger)?

Seems... tenuous and there are real world examples that contradict this theory (though it is interesting). Rather than being a trade-off in the brain (as if we're talking about a processor forced to switch tasks) doesn't it make more sense for this to be a byproduct of the structural aspects of language? I think we can address this by referencing other closely related phenomena related to written language. First though, let's talk about language and the brain. In the brain, we have Exner's writing area, Broca's expressive speech area, and Wernicke's receptive speech area but what we don't have... is an area known to directly correlate to the use of written language conceptually (Exner's writing area seems to be responsible for the motor control aspect but not ideation).

One good source for thinking about this are studies done on dyslexia (the general term for disorders that involve difficulty in learning to read or interpret words, letters, and other symbol) and agraphia (an acquired neurological disorder causing a loss in the ability to communicate through writing). When looking at reading specifically, brain scans do not show any one area designated for working with written language (other than Exner's in the physical act of writing). Studies on dyslexia are especially relevant here. Instead of being one spot, in brain scans the brain seems to spread the load around several areas working in coordination to produce cognition with written language (dyslexia appearing to be a dysfunction in neural adaption in these areas). Language and memory are just not that cut and dry.

As an example, if you have a person read a word... horse for example... most people will picture the object that word represents, for them the mental image of the object being inexorably tied with it's meaning. However, there are people with Aphantasia who do not have that attachment between a word and a mental image of the object... but they retain a concept of what it is anyway. Many dyslexic/dysgraphic people have a similar experience. They (we in this case) retain the concept separate from a mental picture (even of words themselves). More than that, we now have evidence that recalling a memory actually re-writes the memory IF we retell it to ourselves or others (this is part of why police don't want you telling the story of an incident before they get their report). Without that aspect of telling the story though, if we are merely struck by a memory but do not dwell on it, we are far less likely to force it into the confines of language and re-write it.

The whole idea that our brain physically borrowed processing power from memory to make language seems pretty silly given how complex a task language is for the brain (not to mention how language shapes our interpretation of reality structurally). Additionally, I'd say we didn't re-task some other area because nothing in our evolutionary background would have been transferable to the level of abstraction we use when writing. Given what we know about the the formation of memory and it's intersection with language as well as those reading disorders, I just don't see other science backing this theory. Though they've built a very cool primate facility and it was neat watching you square off with the chimps.

The test is great for showing off how intelligent chimps are. But it says nothing about our evolutionary differences. This task is more difficult for an adult mind because you're using numbers. Our perceived advantage (the knowledge of numbers) is actually a disadvantage. A human brain is trained to count one at a time. So when you first see the screen, you look for the number 1 then 2, then 3... The chimp instead sees the whole screen at once, then "simply" taps the screen in the order in which he was taught. 
It would be enlightening to see how the chimps were trained in the first place and if a human were capable of being trained in the same way. The test could be constructed with different colors or shapes just as well and without the inherent bias.

I wonder how you would have performed with symbols other than digits. Us humans have extensive experience with numbers and their meaning, while the chimps only see them as "game shapes". By showing numbers in a short flash, instead of capturing the image, you might be trying to interpret the numbers instead. In other words, making a human do the test is like making a human describe the color of text while the text actually reads another color (EG "BLUE" written in red letters, and you have to say "RED"). Someone who couldn't speak or read english would have no problem in saying the color of the text instead of the word, because a non-english person cannot read the word, so there is no conflicting information

There is a pretty easy to learn trick to doing those puzzles. Don't try to remember the numbers at all. Trace the pattern. One can just draw the lines connecting the squares in the order of the numbers and one only needs to remember the pattern long enough to retrace is. Most tricks that shift a memory task to the most powerful part of the brain by making it a visualization task make the task easier. In this case one doesn't even need to remember then numbers as sequential data, but instead just remember the imaginary image of the numbers connected and then retrace it.

Some things have already been pointed out by other people and I just wanted to sum those up and add another one:
1. The chimp was allegedly the best one they have and he had who knows how much training in this test.
2. Michael on the other hand had to learn the rules (not so hard as he already knew how to count) and certainly did not train for this task.
3. Most importantly, Michael is used to write stuff down. It has been shown that illiterate people have much better memories than people that know how to write. And the ability to write is quite young, at most 10’000 years which in evolutionary timelines is absolutely nothing.

I have to agree with others, that this video was a bit disappointing. What these Chimps can do is certainly impressive, that’s not the point. But some statements really annoyed me. They said, they had never done these kind of tests with a (trained) human but minutes later they said that the memories of chimps far surpassed those of humans.

I think the difference in performance we observe can be explained by the fact that since the invention of writing, humans no longer have to train their memories as hard as they had to. To quote Einstein: “Never memorize something you can look up.”

People sure seem to confuse short term memory with working memory a lot. Working memory is when you manipulate information in your memory while simultaneous continuing to take in information like if I asked you to remember the last words of all my sentences in order while I continue talking without stopping to give you a chance to remember and you listen to me and also remember what I was talking about. So in short, you're listening to me and remembering it while handling other information in your head before directing your recall.

With the video's task, all you really need to do is remember the numbers as they appear then direct your recall after. That's short term memory.

I think attention is what is explaining this more then the species difference.

This study may actually prove an hypothesis that I have made about 20 years ago.

My idea is that attention opens access to sensorial memory input following the filters of our attention (focus).

I actually believe that from birth we are restricted by our needs. Eventually by our. Desires also. We start establishing a hierarchy of priorities in reaching for those and establish an economy of resources and effort at doing so.

Following that hierarchy, some become more and more like fantazies and eventually fade out and dorm what is called the subconscious.

So as we mature, our focus is defining itself towards sets of preferences and we specialize at reaching for those.

Yet between feelings of fulfilment, our spare times allow us to reach for secondary priorities. And we grow slowly in our hability to achieve some of them.

And that is how I believe our attention become more focused following the general "passions" that are the most recurant and vivide.

And only the sensorial memory content that is expected to lead in the resolution of our general organic economical set of oriority is actually rendered accessible for processing by the attention filters.

That explain why old monkeys perform as bad as adult humans.

Something interesting I found while Michael was doing the 0.5 second test. When the numbers would flash, even disregarding time to memorize the numbers, I found that I physically didn't have enough time to even move my eyes over all of the numbers to see them. I remember reading somewhere once upon a time (and I don't know how accurate this is) that while humans have a field of view of nearly 180 degrees, only about 4% of the field of vision is actually in focus (hence why we have to move our eyes when reading instead of just staring at the middle of the text). Clearly the chimps had no problems seeing all of the numbers in the allotted time. I wonder, do chimps' eyes have a larger field of focus than human eyes do? Or is it perhaps more of a reaction time/eye speed thing? Just wondering if the chimps may also have more biological advantages beyond differences in the brain.

Our current theory of evolution doesn't make sense.
If we started with hips protruding rearward, the first generation to have hips closer to ours wouldn't be a full adaptation. It would be a partial shift, and would not provide the advantage of neither extra height nor extra mobility. Due to Darwinism it would therefore not survive as well as those with a fully rearward hip, who would run faster than the new adaptation.
Evolution is claimed to take hundreds of generations, but why would any partial evolution survive at all, considering the uselessness of a hip structure halfway between human and ape?
How did eyes come to be? or our multitude of bone structures? Partial evolutions in any of these would be so far inferior to their previous counterparts they would be immediately eradicated without continuing the cycle.

This makes me wonder: Such a detailed spatial memory would really help in things like path finding, geometry, and similar math. The fact that Michael couldn't get past 3 in the high speed task reminds me of an anthropological study. There are tribes in the amazon that not only don't have math, but don't even have words for quantities past 3. Ie: They have words for, "one," "two," and "many." If language comes at the expense of spatial memory, maybe that means it also indirectly comes at a cost to mathematical ability. If so, there may be truth to urban myth that some people are words people and others are numbers people. Mathematical intuition might partially be a kind of "evolutionary reversal." One might go so far as to say that certain language disorders are an extreme instance of this, in the case of things like "savant syndrome."

I think this test is fundamentally flawed, and proves nothing about the hypothesis. The fact is, a professional chess player can memorize a real chess layout in a minute and perfectly recreate it from memory. Someone who doesn't play chess couldn't ever do so. The fact is, Micheal is an inexperienced player, and Ayumu is the greatest player in the entire world. A human could easily play just as well as these chimps, if they were doing it as often as they do. Once your brain gets use to how the game works, i'm sure it would become easy. At the very least, i think a human could do 7 numbers like this in less than 1 second if they practice every day for a week. Getting up to 9 in .5 seconds would be harder, but i'm still sure plenty of humans could do it given enough time to practice, say a month or two maybe.

Wait a second, this begs the question: How the heck do you teach an ape the values of written numbers? Enumeration isn't even the same concept as ordination, and the symbology of written numbers is yet a third thing. How do you teach a non-linguistic being that a thing shaped like a "7"  represents a concept of something 1 less than the thing represented by an "8" and one more than a "6", and which in turn is more than a "4"? A chimpanze would need to grasp these abstract mathematical, really philosophical, concepts before you could even begin to teach her/him/it to play a tap-the-numbers-in-increasing-order-of-numeric-value-hidden-button-game. It's not enough to see that six bananas is more bananas than four or even five. You must understand the order of the entire decimal numeral set based on the numeric value of the concepts so represented by the numeral characters themselves. Human children learn this by rote verbalization, "one-two-three" like a nursery rhyme, and only later fill in the concepts of relative sizes and the recognition of what is really a second set of letters. (Ai? Artifical Intelligence?) Huh? How?

Interesting episode.  I see a couple of glaring issues however.  First, has a controlled test on humans who have the same amount of time to train on the test been done.  This type of test is a skill that can be improved so taking someone off the street who has not had the same exposure is not a meaningful test.  Train several children from a very early age to play this game and then compare results.  Second,  while the chimp they keep showing is the young male, is he representative of the average?  There are many humans that do tasks or skills much much better than the average person but we do not use these outliers as a description of the species as a whole.  This episode is filled with really bad science.

It's actually  scientifically  possible to prove or disprove this hypothesis of this guy by connecting a mobile FMRI scanner or sensors to the head of the chimpanzees while they do these short term tests. And it is not stated if every chimpanzee is able to do the hardest ones or only the best ones. It is same in our own species. We have some people better than the others in some certain skills. Some Savants and some normal guys who has the incredible amount of calculation abilities. They are able to tell how many dots exist on a screen like 138 in 0.5 second. Also, his hypothesis makes sense from an environmental perspective as well: on the long, flat savannas we moved to, you can see for MILES around. So you can see enemies coming from much further away for far longer, and have much more time to decide and react, and thus don't need to memorize things as quickly.

By contrast, since the plains are so spread out and we had to go much further afield to find food then our chimp cousins in their trees, we needed a way to communicate more effectively over long distances with our pack. Sure, basic sounds can sort of get the job done, but as distance increases, the chance to be misunderstood grows greater, mistaking a "predator" warning for a "food" welcome, for example. So there was pressure for us to develop better verbal communication abilities to minimize those misunderstandings.

It actually leads me to wonder if we might have developed an imagination due to our greater vocal variety - as our vocal cords got more sophisticated and our groups started centering around such communication for survival, it seems natural we'd start speaking all the time as a way to practice and check-in with each other. And doing it enough, our ancestors were bound to make mistakes and make sounds that meant nothing...and sounds that MIGHT mean something, being just on the cusp (like if I were to say "figure" but you hear something like "figor" because I'm half a mile away and shouting).

I can imagine some of our ancestors (with a helpful genetic mutation or two) getting good at "interpreting" those signals, which would lead to them getting better at interpreting a different variety of sounds and their permutations and half-hearings (allowing for "food" to diversify into "meat" and "vegetable" sounds; then to "herbivore","carnivore","fruit","grain"; then to "zebra","gazelle","mammoth","hyena",etc...) which could snowball and eventually lead to us (as the good doctor states) to start proactively come up with potential sounds that don't mean anything YET but that might so we can teach other members and future generations, as the precursor to our modern imaginations.

Okay I have a couple of drunken comments on the scientific aspects of this experiment.
One: The chimps are obviously at least a little used to, and therefore, trained to this exercise.
I assume that if we had Michael put in a cage for years doing this for food, he might get marginally better quite soon.
The best way to see a clear difference would be to have michael (a human man, who, beside knwoing the order of numerals zero to nine doesn't know the exercize) and a trained chimpanzee (trained, but ONLY to know, as michael does, the order of numerals zero to nine, and a stranger to the test itself as michael is) square off. These results would be more telling, I think.
But it might be very difficult to have the chimp understand the purpose or rules of the exercize.
Two (and that's the most important one): I think there is something about the number that doesn't help chimpanzees here, and does give the human an edge, but still, it could go the other way totally: Chimps don't know what numbers mean. If you held up three fingers to their face, they could not choose between 1, 5 and 3 on a screen without preparation.
I'm not exactly sure how that can affect the experiment, but I'd like to see it done on both human and Chimp without numerals, but that would mean changing the exercise completely, either showing meaningless symbols one after the other on the screen and then asking you to point them out in order, or telling you the order of a set of meaningless symbols (like numbers, say ♀ is first, then ☼ is second and ◄ is third) and then having them appear simultenaously on the screen and asking you for the right order, finally.
Nevertheless. Compelling stuff.

I wonder if the actual way in which the numbers are memorised has been tested. I suspect most humans will try to tackle this the same way as me, and will try to memorise the position of the numbers in order. Perhaps the chimps (who don't understand the numbers but know the sequence to press them in) simply remember what number is in each place, and then sort the order out later. I.e. they take a mental snapshot and then go through that snapshot to find the order in which to click.
This could probably be tested by not having the numbers all be shown at the same time, but to go on and off in an non-numerical order.

This is interesting but there are a few arguments I feel are not answered in this episode at least, though I haven't read the detailed study reports admittedly.

First, it looks like the chimps are being trained in recognising the numbers slowly first. If a human participant put in an equal amount of hours as the chimpanzees are doing to train to say Ayumu's level, would the results be that different? You could use made up numerals that humans are not familiar with in order to make it a fair comparison perhaps. Seems like pitting an amateur guitarist against Hendrix. What seems impossible may well just be practice and then tacit intuition.

Second, when I tried to remember the positions of the numbers on the 0.5 second trial, I felt that my vision was not broad enough to even look at the whole thing quick enough, perhaps the vision of chimps and humans is a little different. V-Sauce in one of his previous videos (a long time ago) showed that the focused vision of humans is about the size of your finger nail at an arm's length. Would humans be able to do it better if they sat further from the screen?

Third, I don't understand why there would be a trade off with brain function. That wasn't really explained other than to say if one gets bigger the other has to get smaller. But again, our brains have gotten bigger than smaller primates so why all of a sudden is there a limit?

Lastly, I don't think that what distinguishes homo sapiens from other primates is our ability to share. All primates appear to share. I think it's our ability to be so damn greedy. We have places to store all our stuff and we somehow came up with the crazy notion of 'owning' land. No animal even owns clothes let alone a bank account full of money and a house and a car. Sharing is something we are capable of, but certainly not our defining feature.

EDIT: lots of folks seem to think I said we don't share, and that only humans are greedy. This isn't what I said. The sheer heights to which human greed has soared, is the point I'm making. Also I didn't say it's our only characteristic or only defining one, just that it is one. So calm those quivering starfish.

Mozart did not memorize all the notes in the Pope's mass, he understood its structure, and by understanding the patterns and ornamentation mechanisms, he could be able to reconstruct the whole thing. This kind of abstraction is what is absent from apes, and since they do not have it, they do not need it: they fail to see the more complex, but what we still think it's difficult because of this cognitive cane, they ace it straight away. That's also how chessplayers can reconstruct a match position from scratch.

I had a professor in college by the name of Dr. Marc Meyer. He taught biological anthropology and he spoke about this exact topic. How chimps were able to memorize such situations with ease. He theorized it has something to do with the way they swing through trees and memorize the location, and the order of the branches they want to grab. For instance, when a chimp is swinging ever so quickly through the trees, it has limited time to look, and even decide what branches would be most effective to grab in order to hunt, run away or whatever the case may be. I don’t know much about what he was working on, but that was all he told us. Very interesting stuff

For example, remembering someone's phone number by each singular digit is hard, but break it up to area code, first three digits, last 4 digits and now you're just remembering 3 pieces of information. Idk if maximizing on this part of the human short term memory to think forward and compartmentalize and chunk information together would increase reaction time on our part for test like these. So in the case of the second 9 number test Micheal took, memorizing it in chunks of 3 so 1 to 2 to 3, then 4 to 5 to 6, and lastly 7 to 8 to 9 are each their 3 point line and now 3 pieces of info instead of 9.

I have a theory. It’s not that chimps are better but worse at memory. Number, screens, location, company and many more data points are involved and we have to go through a large data base of previous information related to all those things. There fore it becomes harder for use to filter through all this and perform at that heigh speed. From our past experience, our brain may filter out few things as un necessary or irrelevant. Maybe a lot of brain power is consumed into processing and filtering out all that information or correlations. Given enough time we will still be able to do it. Chimps on the other hand don’t not remember that my relations hence less things to filter and get  faster easily with practice. I bet a human might be slow but with increasing complexity will be able to keep up, chimps will have a threshold beyond which that be impossible for them to cope up and perform.

Change the numbers into shapes that Micheal's mind wouldn't try to "read." Don't use shapes that have names like "triangle", "sun", "square", or "arrow" either. Our human minds are trying to translate the pictures into words of our native language, and this translation time is what's causing skills like photographic memory to diminish. I.e.: Instead of capturing WHERE the shapes/symbols are on the screen, your mind was reading the number "4" to you in your head and trying to hunt down where number "5" is.. but by that time, the image has already disappeared.

Of course, to the chimps these are not numbers in the sense that we know verbally. They are shapes, and they've learned that the one that looks like a stick standing up from the ground needs to be tapped first. If they really wanted to turn these tests from "studying chimps" into "studying chimps vs human", then they'd have to level the playing field by not using numbers. And have both chimp and human use new shapes and organically learn (by their individual intuitions) the order of them. I guarantee you, with enough time and repetition (remember, these tests are like a 1/4th of the chimp's life), a human can match that speed.
