Maybe the issue here is, that those Chimpansees get to see and learn this task from very early on in their childhood, when the brain is easily adapting. Kinda like you learn a language super fast being a child, it becomes waaay harder to learn a language at such speed being an adult. So maybe those Chimpansees started to see this test early enough in their brains adaptation to life, so that their brains developed a kind of "image buffer", where they can store one frame.
One might need to wait until a Chimpansee is an adult, and then present them with the test for the first time. Will it still outperform a human by such a huge margin? Or will the results be very similar, in which case this is not such a robust evidence for the Tradeoff Hypothesis any more.

I'm not questioning the experiment.

But. I have to mention the function of metikasma. Well I only know the Greek name, but I can explain it and how it works.

Metikasma (in Greek, though I don't know the English terminology) is when you stare at a light source for too long and then close your eyes and you can still see the light right in front of you everywhere you "look". If the light source has a specific shape - you will keep on seeing that exact copy of that shape and you can make that happen for more than a minute or even more than a couple of minutes before it fades out...

So, what if the chimps actually have different eyes that can keep more light from the screen for more time than Human eyes can, and they don't really remember the numbers ... they just see them right in front of them?

This reminds me of an experiment with humans and gorillas, I believe. A clear box with knobs and a food pellet was shown to children and the apes, with elaborate and not all necessary instructions to get the pellet. The children followed the overly complicated method to a tee (mimicry) while the apes just did the most efficient method. Perhaps they perceived more detail and ignored the unnecessary movements?

This was quite a disappointing video. A story of bad science. They compare trained chimps with untrained humans, and make assumptions based on perceived differences, without evidence. The first basic mistake was not considering training as a variable. Then they made bold assumptions based on a weak, qualitative correlation (speech or communication ). Correlation and causation are different things, and conclusions are even harder to come by without a reliable quantification of speech (or rather 'communication').

Visual reverb, a sort of image burn into the receptors at the back of the eye or brain sustained perception of the perceived flash of numbers. With repeated practice dudes could probably do what the chimps are doing. I noticed I can sometimes still see a ghost of the numbers in my minds eye after the flash of numbers.

Essentially there is an extremely small amount of processing required to react almost instantaneously to the numbers with nearly zero effort. A bit like typing or speaking but only with a tiny fraction of the processing power required. Picking the right numbers fast enough is probably easier than actually moving the arm and hands correctly via predictive calculations through space and time. I’m thinking that even insects could do similarly fast memory and motor manoeuvres, probably faster.

There is a fundamental flaw in the argument that for language to take a larger place in the brain something must be lost. If you choose to believe evolutionary theory, they brains evolved to contain and support new functions, which immediately contradicts the idea that some functionality must be lost for some other to be gained.

"claws"
shows ghost crab
innacurate. Crabs rarely if ever use their claws for defense. Those are strictly used for either eating or settling territorial disputes.

Their main mode of defense is their speed, as having side-to-side movement allows them to significantly simplify their leg movements and thus diminishing their energy consumption, hence why shrimps and lobsters use the caridoid escape reaction (flick of the tail) to escape, because their gait doesn't allow for fast speeds. Meanwhile crabs are comparatively incredibly fast, allowing them to quickly hide under rocks (marine crabs) or burrows (land crabs). This is also why sea crabs have a generally flattened appearance, it's to allow them to fit under rocks more easily.

Claws are only ever used as a last resort, like a lizard's detachable tail, a crab can sometimes dig it's claw into a predator to distract it, which will most often cause the claw to be potentially detached from the animal.
Otherwise, most crab species (mostly land-based ones) will attempt a "lunge" to intimidate, which doesn't actually do anything other than frighten whatever it's trying to get away from (I had my pet land crab "pinch" me a couple times after a successful lunge, it really doesn't actually do anything).

Ironic how you used the atlantic ghost crab here as an example, animals that almost never use their claws for defense. Their main modes of defense are actually speed (notice how most ghost crabs have a significantly more muscular ischium-merus one their walking legs compared to most other crab species) and their camouflage (atlantic ghost crabs can actually change the color of the top of their carapace based on the color of the sand they reside on without molting).

As a biologist l went off on a tangent of looking at genetics. It had nothing to do with my job. l was working in the aerospace field, but was intrigued by new discoveries in DNA and the claim that we share 97% with chimps, but we share almost that much with many species. There isn't a single species of bacteria to humans that doesn't have pretty much the same coding DNA. What makes humans completely different from the great apes isn't our DNA, but our abstract ability. As an example, a 3 year old child understands the expression "Once upon a time",  but no other creature does. As the video states the chimps only live in the 'here and now.' They have no concept of "tomorrow".

I'm curious how much of an effect the fact that the test is using linguistic symbols has, as when trying to memorize the patterns on screen myself my thought was "I can't read that fast". But is what the chips are doing reading? A human doing the test is presumably processing each numeral as a number, as a symbol that represents a concept; reading them. Do the chimps not do that? They obviously understand that these symbols go in a certain order. Do they understand that the symbols can stand for counts of things? Might a human perform better on a variant of the test using non-linguistic images, like say cartoon faces of different animals? We'd have to learn what the right order of animals is, but presumably the chips had to learn what the right order of numerals is. Maybe the problem slowing humans down is that we're trying to read the numbers, instead of just seeing a picture and remembering what that picture looks like.

It makes me think of the difference between "system 1" and "system 2" processes, where system 1 is "muscle memory" and system 2 is deliberate thoughtful action. The latter seems like it would be highly connected to the same parts of our brain that handle language and abstract reasoning, and that is known already to be much slower than system 1; that's why you can screw up your ability to effortlessly do something you're good at by thinking about it too much. I wonder if a human could perform better at this test if there were a way, like I speculate above, to bypass system 2 and let the faster, non-linguistic parts of our brains do the work for us.

"Learning many languages. To learn many languages fills the memory with words instead of with facts and ideas, even though in every man, memory is a vessel that can take in only a certain limited amount of content. Also, learning many languages is harmful in that it makes a man believe he is accomplished, and actually does lend a certain seductive prestige in social intercourse; it also does harm indirectly by undermining his acquisition of well-founded knowledge and his intention to earn men's respect in an honest way. Finally, it is the axe laid to the root of any finer feeling for language within the native tongue; that is irreparably damaged and destroyed. The two peoples who produced the greatest stylists, the Greeks and the French, did not learn any foreign languages.
But because the commerce of men must become increasingly cosmopolitan and, for example, a proper merchant in London must be able to make himself a necessary evil. When it finally reaches an extreme, it will force mankind to find a remedy for it, and in some far-off future time everyone will know a new language, a language of commerce at first, then a language of intellectual intercourse generally, and this as surely as there will one day be aerial navigation. Why else would the science of linguistics have studied the laws of language for a century and assessed what is necessary, valuable, and successful about each separate language!"

If I understand correctly, ayumu was born in captivity and has been doing the tests since he was born, for idk how many years but I'm guessing around 10. We always hear about how the human brain is so flexible and adaptable, especially at early ages, so much so that some kids who keep repeating the same actions all the time and training again and again become prodigies with "talent" unlike anyone has ever seen before, and the younger the brain, the better it is at learning and the faster it adapts.

Isn't it the same for chimpanzee brains ? Could it not be that ayumu's brain adapted really well to the tests because he's been doing it from an early age, and from what I understand nearly every day for years ? Could a human not reach his level if he had the same experience ? Granted we can't actually test it on a child, but it's still widely known how specialized the human brain can become given enough stimuli over a long enough period.

This really reminds me of Jean M. Auels books-series The Earth Children (first book called Clan of The Cave Bear). The book-series shows a difference between Neanderthals and early Homo-sapiens similar to what is being discussed here. It describes Neanderthals as being able to call upon a inherent memory of the clan, in other words; the children seem to pick up on survival tactics and clan-norms, -values and -tradition way quicker than the main protagonist Ayla; She is a Homo-sapiens, and feels like she has difficulties learning the same things like her Neanderthal clan-mates because she can't acces this inherent clan-memory. The Neanderthals, in the books, communicate with sign-language, while Ayla (who, with great difficulty, grows up learning sign language as well) and her, later on, Homo-sapien family already have the ability to speak and have a spoken language to communicate.

I believe the neanderthals in the books are able to pick up on things in their clan só quickly that Ayla thinks they have a inherent memory, is because of their lack of capability for spoken language. They still use a language - sign language - but it's very different from spoken language as it uses visual symbols to communicate; something that the neanderthals in the book are good at learning (I.e. Picking up on visual information quickly)

Forgive me for committing the sin of commenting before finishing the video (I'm 10 minutes in so if this does come up later, my apologies), but suppose the Cognitive Tradeoff Hypothesis is absolutely true; does it perhaps offer an explanation as to how autistic traits arise? Perhaps humans evolved certain genes that when switched on cause various neural structures evident in the primate brain (leading to the photgraphic type memory) to not form, in favour of the strcutures responsible for language and high level social capabilities. My suggestion would therefore be that in individuals with austistic traits, these genes are not correctly switched on - hence why you get individuals that are autistic with incredible talents, often at the cost of communication and social skills.
This is highly interesting and I hope that this gets covered at some point, even if only briefly, on my psychology degre.

These are all things I recognize from TV documentaries and I always found it annoying. Now I don't necessarily think the whole mind field series is bad, because there are some interesting topics and findings in some of them still. But I would like it if mind field were presented in the old vsuace way, where it was a lot of information from different angles and switching topics frequently like you mentioned in your ted talk to keep the audience interested. You also never really dumbed things down for the general audience in your old videos, or didn't explain trivial things much. So not only do the topics seem to be less complicated but also the narration spends too much time on simple things. Together they make for a worse experience than your old videos. I don't believe this hypothesis to be true.  I believe that the added complexity of language makes it slower for us to absorb information since we have to translate it into our own internal narrative language so we can refer to it later when trying to communicate. Evolution happens based on what is being USED to survive.
So if one group have the ability for 20 generations but didn't use it in the last 15 they wouldn't notice if the ability disappeared because of a lack of targeted mating based on that trait.
Losing traits is a slow process that needs to involve lack of usage.
Gaining traits can happen over a onehanded amout of generations because of a single individuals random mutation that FAVORS the survivalpattern already in use.
